story:
Studio Update # 1!



The Pitch

With our new E.P,  we are attempting to make a new kind of impact on the music world by creating a sound that is fresh, unique, and still Prospect Hill. For the last year, we have been writing new music and quietly preparing our comeback behind closed doors with designs on taking Prospect Hill to the next level. As most people are aware, the music industry is a shrewd business and takes more than just talent to achieve a high level of success. That being said, our current financial situation is not conducive to creating the impact we would need to catapult us into the national spotlight. This is where you, the fans, come into play. With your help, we feel that our opportunity to make it in this business has never been more promising. With the release of our new cover single, "Don't Tell 'Em" by Jeremih, we have given you an idea of the direction we are heading and there is plenty more where that came from. So, will you help us continue to move forward and make a long-lasting effect on the music world?




The Goal & Prizes

    In the initial phase of this campaign, our goal is to raise $25,000. If we are successful, our plan is to invest money into all the areas necessary in refining a successful musical project (i.e. production, marketing, touring, etc.). One goal is finding and hiring upper-level producers that share the same vision as we do and will work to make our music the best that it can be. Another goal is to organize a solid marketing campaign via social-media and other various sources to generate an interest on a national level. Needless to say, we have a clear and concise plan for any donations made by you to us. In donating, you are eligible for some of the various perks and prizes that we are offering depending on the amount in which you are willing to donate. Check out all the prizes listed in the "Perks" section of our page.


GOAL 1: $25,000
- 5 - 8 song E.P recorded (details below)

- Rent the studio

- The ability to fly in a couple different producers, pay for their time and travel

- Hire specific mix engineers for specific songs

- Get album mastered 

- Bring in some featured artists that we would like to showcase

- artwork and packaging for album

GOAL 2: $50,000
- 5 - 8 song E.P recorded (details below)

- Rent the studio

- The ability to fly in a couple different producers, pay for their time and travel

- Hire specific mix engineers for specific songs

- Get album mastered 

- Bring in some featured artists that we would like to showcase

- artwork and packaging for album
- Music video for each song
- Half PR campaign

GOAL 3: $75,000
- 5 - 8 song E.P recorded (details below)

- Rent the studio

- The ability to fly in a couple different producers, pay for their time and travel

- Hire specific mix engineers for specific songs

- Get album mastered 

- Bring in some featured artists that we would like to showcase

- artwork and packaging for album
- Music video for each song
- Half Radio campaign
- Half PR campaign
- Half Advertisement Campaign

GOAL 4: $100,000
- 5 - 8 song E.P recorded (details below)

- Rent the studio

- The ability to fly in a couple different producers, pay for their time and travel

- Hire specific mix engineers for specific songs

- Get album mastered 

- Bring in some featured artists that we would like to showcase

- artwork and packaging for album
- Music video for each song
- Full Radio campaign
- Full PR campaign
- Full Advertisement Campaign
- Lyric video for each song
- Full Length Documentary chronicling the past as well as recording new EP and all events surrounding it. An inside look at it all as well as each persons name who donated in the credits.
- E.P of B-Sides

The Impact

    Nearly four years ago, we launched a campaign similar to this one and, within a few days, we accumulated enough money in donations to produce the music video for our single, "Come Alive." By contributing to our campaign this time around, you would be granting us the opportunity to make decisions that focus on the quality of our music rather than the cost. We will be able to operate with more flexibility and take steps toward building a successful business by making the presentation and production-quality of our music the top priority. The benefits are endless in having additional resources to achieve the vast number of goals that we have set out for ourselves and we are asking you, the fans, to help Prospect Hill into the next stage of our careers.

Spread The Word!

    If you are not able to donate, there are plenty of ways that you can help us out. The best way to help is to tell your family, friends and anyone that you believe might be interested in contributing to our campaign. Otherwise, just keep checking in on us and providing feedback on anything new we might release. Please, share this link and use the sharing tools provided by the IndieGoGo website. Thank you so much!

story:
Short Summary

I am a singer, conductor and musician living and working in south Devon.  One of my passions is for opera - and for performing opera.  It is a sad state that there is no longer an operatic society in Devon which performs operas (as opposed to musicals or Gilbert and Sullivan).  There are singers in the county who would like to perform operas, and so I have set up Red Earth Opera as a project group to perform at least one opera per year, and possibly more.

We are starting from a base of nothing - no funds, just enthusiasm and determination.  We have two performances booked for March 2015, both of which should generate some income, but I am currently funding everything else from my own (not very deep pocket).  We have singers, we have musicians, and we have an audience as I did a similar venture last year when we performed Purcell's "Dido and Aeneas" at the Teignmouth Classical Music Festival.  They invited us back, and we shall be performing a semi-staged version of Mozart's Idomeneo in English with narration instead of recitative, and with an orchestra.

We are also offering places in the orchestra and chorus to talented young musicians from Torbay - these are being supported by a donation from the Torbay Music Hub.

We have a cast, we have some orchestral players, we have the music, and we have had our first rehearsal.  The performances are on Sunday 8th March at the Teignmouth Classical Music Festival, and on Saturday 28th March at Hannah's at Seale Hayne.

What We Need & What You Get

We need donations of all sizes to pay expenses for soloists travelling to sing from London, Hertfordshire, Wales and Bristol.

We have paid for a translation as there is none published,

We need to pay for our rehearsal venues, and for musicians for the orchestra where we cannot find players willing to give their services.

As conductor and organiser, I am not planning to take a fee unless and until all of the other musicians have received payment or expenses.  If I do take a fee, I shall cap it at £100 (given I have already spent over 100 hours arranging music, promoting and organising rehearsals, marketing etc, this is nothing like a commercial payment).

If you donate £25 or more, then you will be offered a complementary ticket for either performance. Donations of £5 or more will receive a ballpoint pen or pencil with the Red Earth Opera Logo..  Donations of £50 or more will also receive a white T-shirt with the Red Earth Logo printed on it.  (please indicate size).

The Impact

There is a demand for this - this is our second year.  There is no other such opportunity in Devon.  My aim is to present opera which is different to the large touring companies, or the corporate opera pops, and which is approachable and enjoyable for those who are not already keen on opera.  I also want to give performers opportunities at all levels.  Our major soloists this year are all singers giving their services because they want to learn the roles.  I am certain some of them will go on to great things.

Risks & Challenges

These performances will happen - this year.  At the moment, I am underwriting, and very possibly subsidising this because I am passionate about it.  I make my money from music, but this project is never going to make me any money.  I would like to be able to set up a company so that we can continue with this, and to grow it into the future.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to help financially, I would love admin support for marketing, creation of a web-site etc.  I would also like to set up a full management board so we can open a dedicated bank account and look at obtaining charitable status.

story:
First of all, thank you for coming to this page and showing your willingness to support this project!

Thank you  everyone who supported the original campaign. We reached 51%! This campaign is meant to take us all the way to the recording studio!!


WHO AM I?

Hi, I'm Amaka. Singer. Songwriter. Dreamer.

Born and raised in Germany, I have moved around a bit and the experiences I made flow into my music. My songs celebrate the light that gets us through dark times.
It is music for the soul with percussive elements and influences like Blues and Reggae.

I left the certainty of work in London's media industry to return to Germany and focus on music. It wasn't easy but I managed. With my band I've performed throughout Europe, and I have also had the pleasure of singing alongside renowned blues and jazz musicians, like Marla Glen and Hans-Günther Adam.

"When will you release an album?" is  a question I get asked a lot by friends, family and fans. It has been a long time coming, but I am finally ready!! I've spent the last two years writing songs and am surrounded by an amazing team of musicians and production people. We are all set to record and release my debut EP  and I have been saving toward it - but I need your support to help make this dream a reality!


SUPPORT

My goal is to raise $4,000. Recording and releasing an album is VERY expensive. With your support, I will be able to pay for:

  • The musicians
  • Mixing / Mastering
  • Studio hire
  • Marketing / Promotion
  • CD production

The best part is, you can select something from a wide range of
THANK YOU ITEMS or "Perks" that you can't get anywhere else but here! 


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Your support means the world to me.
If you cannot donate, no worries! You can help in so many ways:

  • Spread the word about this campaign. Tell your friends, family and the press!
  • You can use the Indiegogo share tools!

Producing my first album is beyond exciting - and I get to share my journey with you!! What an honour and joy it would be if someday I could share my music with you in every way possible!

Once again, thank you for visiting my campaign site!

OneLove,

Amaka
amakamusic@hotmail.com

[P.s.: Credit Card donations are preferable as they do not incur fees to the payee.]

story:
At the end of June I'll be heading out west with my travel partner Jessa Jordan.

This will be my most ambitious project since having a stroke three years ago. I will be photographing Jessa along with other models at diners, drive-ins, quirky motels and other road side attractions along Route 66, Main Street America.

As we travel across the United states I will edit and send images to get printed. Days after arriving in LA I will be showing my work in a gallery.

I plan on using the money for prints, publication of a book and to survive on the road for the next few months. I will keep my personal expenses to a minimum by couch surfing, camping and sleeping in the car.

Risks & Challenges

The biggest risk will be car trouble that I couldn't fix myself. One solution would be to have a print sale.

story: All of our gear was stolen while on tour in San Antonio, TX and now we are on tour with almost no gear of our own. Help us get some new instruments to keep playing!!!
story_txt: All of our gear was stolen while on tour in San Antonio, TX and now we are on tour with almost no gear of our own. Help us get some new instruments to keep playing!!!

story:
Friends (both old and new),

I have spent my entire life absorbing the musical traditions around me. From riding in the car and listening to Mexican norteño music with my father, to my first high school jazz band, the experiences that I have cherished most in my life have been pushing me towards this moment: when, after four years of a rigorous higher musical education from Bard College, I finally feel ready to take everything musical I've ever loved and make my own statement.

That's right everyone, it's my first EP!

And for such an occasion, I want to pull out all the stops, to provide you all with the best possible musical product I can conjure. In preparing the material, I have written pieces that require a veritable HAZMAT team of (17!) musicians, or to give you a better idea, about half a big band. 

And what exactly will we be bringing you? Very good question. As intimated previously, I've spent years digging through a whole catalogue of different musical styles, each of which have assumed a coveted place in the musical landscape. 

Everything from jazz:

        A little ballet jazz tune I wrote and arranged called "Dance for Patricia."


To classical:


A short clip of the second movement from Beethoven's "Pathetique."


To Harlem stride piano:


It took some time to figure that one out.

Now, after having done all of that, the only logical step is to put them all together and create something completely new! That's right; by taking apart these styles and putting them back together again, we (all 17 of us) want to create a new kind of sound. 

Not only that, but we want to do it live. No auto-tune, no overdubbing, no nets to catch us; nothing but all of us in the studio together with our instruments to pave the way. 

Now, as you can imagine, not many engineers, much less studios, would be inclined to take on such a project. But thankfully, we found this guy:

Meet Paul Antonell, Master of the Soundboard, the EP project's Musical Godfather, and the owner/proprieter of The Clubhouse, one of the most illustrious American recording studios, situated in Rhinebeck, NY (coincidentally, a stone's throw from Bard College), and one of the only places big enough to hold us.

When I met with him, not only did he not cringe; his eyes lit up. Soon, we were pacing through the whole studio trying to figure out where to place everyone, documented by my handy-dandy iPhone:

When you meet someone who's that gung-ho for your project, you'd be a fool to say no! 

Which, finally, brings us to our musicians. I know for my first journey into recorded music that I would want to take with me as many of my passionate and gifted musical comrades from the Bard years, many of whom have projects of their own. They are:

Ryan MacLean (of Meadowhawks) – Drums, Percussion

Angela Skarpelis – Percussion

Alex "Freedom" Friedman – Percussion

Joe Tisdall – Guitars

Jory Dawidowicz – Bass

Rachel Ana Dobken – Guest Vocals

Ariana Stultz – Backup Vocals

Nelle June Anderson – Backup Vocals

Brianna Reed – Backup Vocals

Spencer Beatbox – Beatbox

Scott Moore – Violin

Trygve Butler – Trumpet

Szabolc Koczur – Trumpet

Cameron West – French Horn

Janos Sutyak – Trombone

Nick Reilingh – Trombone

Derek Fenstermacher (of The New Jersey Symphony!)– Tuba

In addition to all of these fine noisemakers, we'll also be bravely stepping into the studio with a film crew to document the EP's creation, lead by the inimitable Yuxin Huang!

Words cannot describe how excited we all are about this project; so much so that we've already started rehearsing!

Slowly, but surely, we're making our way through the material to get us tight and ready for our recording session on Monday, April 6th through Wednesday, April 8th. 

But we still need your help to get there!

Where You Come In!

As you can see, the vast majority of the money needed will be funneled into the two fundamentals elements of any musical venture: renting the space and compensating the talent.

In renting out The Clubhouse for recording, we not only get the full support of Paul and his team of assistants, but the perks of a basement filled with an exhaustive collection of analog instruments and recording equipment unlike any you've ever seen, plus an entirely separate wing of comfortable bedrooms where we can get some much-needed shut-eye after a 12-hour workday.

On top of that, the space will need to be rented out an additional two days in April for mixing the fruits of our labor.

While I feel blessed to have such a large network of enthusiastic, like-minded artists in my life who are willing to embark with me on this (admittedly) crazy project just for the love of it, I deem it absolutely imperative to properly compensate them for their efforts. The budget for artists' fees includes providing them with the means of transportation and compensation for the time each of them spends at The Clubhouse.

The other half of our colorful pie goes to the smaller things, such as tuning the piano (which will likely have to happen twice over a three-day period), providing full meals for all personnel involved, and paying Yuxin and her crew for their time. 

Put it all together, and we come to a budget of $12,000. 

So What?

It's never been easy for musicians to realize the work they dream up–much less to even make a living! In the post-Spotify world, we need all the help we can get to put us in the places where we can make the music that always has been a crucial extension of peoples' lives. This is why we need you to be the engine of our creative process, to give us that boost we need to give it back in full with all of the time and love we will put into this project.

Thankfully, this is not our first time going into the studio to record super-complicated genre-bending music under a ferocious time limit. A single from last year–an atonal hip-hop/montuno called "Mad King"–speaks to that:


Hot off the success of that experiment, we want to take it to the next level! 

Even if you can't contribute directly to the campaign, if you like what you've heard, and you think this is just crazy enough to work, please share our story with everyone you can. Tweets, 'Grams, Emails; it's all fair game! 

Thanks so much for your time and generosity. I just know that we will make beautiful music together.

With love,

Jesse Featherstone

Spencer Beatbox – Beatbox
Scott Moore – Violin
Trygve Butler – Trumpet
Szabolc Koczur – Trumpet
Cameron West – French Horn
Janos Sutyak – Trombone
Nick Reilingh – Trombone
Derek Fenstermacher (of The New Jersey Symphony!)– Tuba
In addition to all of these fine noisemakers, we'll also be bravely stepping into the studio with a film crew to document the EP's creation, lead by the inimitable Yuxin Huang!
Words cannot describe how excited we all are about this project; so much so that we've already started rehearsing!

Slowly, but surely, we're making our way through the material to get us tight and ready for our recording session on Monday, April 6th through Wednesday, April 8th. 
But we still need your help to get there!   Where You Come In! 

As you can see, the vast majority of the money needed will be funneled into the two fundamentals elements of any musical venture: renting the space and compensating the talent.
In renting out The Clubhouse for recording, we not only get the full support of Paul and his team of assistants, but the perks of a basement filled with an exhaustive collection of analog instruments and recording equipment unlike any you've ever seen, plus an entirely separate wing of comfortable bedrooms where we can get some much-needed shut-eye after a 12-hour workday.
On top of that, the space will need to be rented out an additional two days in April for mixing the fruits of our labor.
While I feel blessed to have such a large network of enthusiastic, like-minded artists in my life who are willing to embark with me on this (admittedly) crazy project just for the love of it, I deem it absolutely imperative to properly compensate them for their efforts. The budget for artists' fees includes providing them with the means of transportation and compensation for the time each of them spends at The Clubhouse.
The other half of our colorful pie goes to the smaller things, such as tuning the piano (which will likely have to happen twice over a three-day period), providing full meals for all personnel involved, and paying Yuxin and her crew for their time. 
Put it all together, and we come to a budget of $12,000.    So What? It's never been easy for musicians to realize the work they dream up–much less to even make a living! In the post-Spotify world, we need all the help we can get to put us in the places where we can make the music that always has been a crucial extension of peoples' lives. This is why we need you to be the engine of our creative process, to give us that boost we need to give it back in full with all of the time and love we will put into this project.
Thankfully, this is not our first time going into the studio to record super-complicated genre-bending music under a ferocious time limit. A single from last year–an atonal hip-hop/montuno called "Mad King"–speaks to that:

Hot off the success of that experiment, we want to take it to the next level! 
Even if you can't contribute directly to the campaign, if you like what you've heard, and you think this is just crazy enough to work, please share our story with everyone you can. Tweets, 'Grams, Emails; it's all fair game! 
Thanks so much for your time and generosity. I just know that we will make beautiful music together.
With love,
Jesse Featherstone

story:
I have been a long time peace activist and worked with disadvantaged and vulnerable people of all stripes my entire life.  This I combined with artistic pursuits to give me a certain balance.

20 years ago I worked as a 'Passive Recreational Tutor' at a Juvenile Justice Centre, teaching pottery.  This is where I first witnessed Music therapy,  I often sat all night watching over an open dorm, where a young man wore headphones to bed to help calm him as he fell asleep to music.

In April, 2014, I was part of a Peace Pilgrimage to Syria to deliver 2 tonnes of Medical Aid to the people suffering in this strife torn country.  During this visit I again witnessed the power of music when visiting internal refugee camps in Syria.  I had encouraged my son to take his guitar and play.  The music crossed all age boundaries, old women danced, children joined in and laughter and clapping rang out with the music.  Raising the funds to deliver instruments to Afghanistan is my latest endeavour, this money will also go towards music teachers.   I will be travelling to Afghanistan in May to this end.  All my travel costs will be paid for by me and will not come out of the instrument fund.  All funds will go toward instruments, tutors and school infrastructure needed.

The benefit to a child learning an instrument is bountiful.  It can help with PTSD,  Musical practice promotes synapse growth that improves all areas of learning.  Playing an instrument is the only human activity that uses both hemispheres of the brain simultaneously which enhances problem solving skills and can also lift children out of both financial poverty and poverty of the soul.

To kick start this,  instruments will be distributed to street kids in Kabul, who are participating in an education program with the Afghan Peace Volunteers.  I have the great hope that this program can be expanded.  How far it is expanded is dependent on your generosity and reaching the first milestone of $10,000.

There is a shortage of instruments in Afghanistan due to the Taliban's ban on music.  Instruments were often used for firewood or were blown up by them.  Apart from the therapeutic aspect of learning an instrument it is important to maintain Afghanistan's culture heritage, of which music was a vibrant part

If this goal is not reached any money raised will still go towards instruments for Afghanistan.  In order to be successful I need your help in disseminating this programme.  Whether you are able to donate or not, please share within your Social Media networks.  I remind my kind funders of the sharing tools available here.

The children of Afghanistan have lived lives most in the West could not even image.  In Kabul alone there are 30,000 odd street kids.  Apart from the benefits outlined above there is the sheer joy of music and Afghan children certainly need more joy in their lives.  There will be hurdles in this programme but with the help of many talented friends involved in the peace movement, human rights and education in Afghanistan and most certainly you, I have every faith any hurdles with be overcome.

Let the music begin!

story:
En Espanol >>

Jump to: The Project -- Budget -- About Stars & Distances -- The Team -- FAQ --


The Project:

To record an innovative, new composition, Stars & Distances by Fredrick Kaufman, which will serve as a special soundtrack for Miami’s new Frost Planetarium at the Patricia and Phillip Frost Museum of Science in downtown Miami's Museum Park.

Our Story:

In the summer of 2014, FGO’s General Director & CEO, Susan T. Danis was approached by conductor Andrew Bisantz with a project proposal: to record composer Fredrick Kaufman's innovative composition Stars & Distances so it could become a special soundtrack to the new Frost Planetarium.

With assistance from Bisantz, composer Fredrick Kaufman, and Frost Science, FGO was able to pull together an enthusiastic team to get this project off the ground. By early fall of 2014, singers had been arranged, a recording company was scheduled to fly down, and donations to fund the project were lining up.

Why We Need YOU!

Just as the recording process began, these anticipated donations did not come through. Although FGO was able to put up enough money to fund the initial recording fees, the project has since been put on hold.

We need you to help fund this special soundtrack to Miami’s new Frost Planetarium at the Patricia and Phillip Frost Museum of Science.


Budget Breakdown

About Stars & Distances:


Stars and Distances is an 18’ work for a 16-voice vocal chamber ensemble. The piece, first conceptualized in 1976, was completed in 1982 and premiered to “great success” in 1986 by the Pacific Lutheran University Chorus. The piece has since been revised in anticipation for this project.

Kaufman on Stars and Distances:

Stars & Distances came to me as I lay on my back one night in Hyde Park, London, staring up at the Cosmos trying to imagine what overwhelming assemblage of specs would sound like if they indeed had a sound. The next day I came back with a telescope and charts I had borrowed from the University of London Astronomy Department.
… I decided to try to identify 15 of the brightest stars in the sky that night.
As I researched those stars I discovered that each one of them had an individual fascinating characteristic … All of them are considerably larger than our sun and many, much more powerful. 
I then set out to work writing the composition.

As Kaufman explains, those 15 stars served as the catalyst for his composition. The piece is divided into 15 parts, each marked by the “individual fascinating” characteristics of the stars which inspired him. Such characteristics include sound quality, volume, complexity, and energy delivered by the 16-voice ensemble.

Throughout the composition we hear essences of undulating scientific and poetry readings by actors John Fleming and Karen Fuller drawn from the brilliant writings of renowned scientists and poets, all related to the subject, Stars and Distances.

Top of Page

The Stars & Distances Team


Fredrick Kaufman, composer

Fredrick Kaufman (b. 1936) is the composer of over one hundred and thirty compositions that have been performed worldwide by orchestras such as the Warsaw Philharmonic, Israel Philharmonic, Czech Radio Orchestra, Lithuanian Philharmonic, Czech National Symphony Orchestra, Jerusalem Symphony, Instrumental Ensemble of Grenoble, London Sinfonietta, Orchestra Novi Musici, Dominican Republic National Orchestra, National Orchestra of Brazil, Los Angeles Philharmonic, New World Symphony the Pittsburgh Symphony orchestras, and Florida Grand Opera. Kaufman is a former Fulbright Scholar, and recipient honors and fellowships from the Endowment of the Arts, the Rockefeller, Guggenheim and Ford Foundations.

Twice nominated for a Pulitzer Prize, Kaufman's Holocaust composition Kaddish, which Bernard Holland of The New York Times described as "having the most expressive writing for strings to be heard today," has been performed over 100 times in the major concert halls of Europe, Eastern Europe, Scandinavia, Israel, South America, Asia and throughout the United States. His works have received prizes at international competitions and have been performed throughout the world at major music festivals. Israeli television has paid tribute to him as a composer in the thirty minute documentary film Fredrick Kaufman-Life of an Artist.

Critics from the New York Times, Newark Star-Ledger, Philadelphia Inquirer, Miami Herald, Jerusalem Post, London Times, Perpignan Independent have described Kaufman's music as “striking…individual…an interesting combination of overwhelming pathos and infectious joy…brought one into the realm of musical genius.”

His Kaminarimon (for Taiko drums and Flamenco dance) has been called "remarkable" and "stunning" and was voted as the number one classical composition of 2002 and "the most imaginative new work of the year" by music critic James Roos of The Miami Herald. String Quartet #6, The Urban was called "stunning" by The New Yorker magazine. The Quartet was nominated by Lukas Foss in 2007 for a Pulitzer Prize.

Kaufman is very excited about his new association with Florida Grand Opera and feels that their spectacular performance of his Stars & Distances will be acclaimed by the public and critics alike.


Andrew Bisantz, conductor

A versatile musician acknowledged for his passionate and commanding leadership from the podium, the exciting young American conductor Andrew Bisantz is quickly building an impressive roster of credits at leading national orchestras and opera companies throughout the country. For his debut with Boston Lyric Opera leading The Turn of the Screw, the Boston Globe selected it as one of the ten top Boston classical music events of 2010. He subsequently returned for productions of Tosca and Madama Butterfly.

Mr. Bisantz joined the music staff of Florida Grand Opera in 2002, first as Assistant Conductor, then as Resident Conductor. He made his FGO mainstage debut in the 2005-06 season, conducting Bizet’s Carmen for the company’s historic final performances at Miami-Dade County Auditorium, and he returned as the 2006-07 Henry C. Clark Conductor to conduct performances of Manon Lescaut. Additionally, he has conducted La cenerentola and La bohème for FGO. 

In recent seasons he’s led acclaimed productions of Don Giovanni (one of South Florida Classical Review’s Ten Best Performances of 2011), Rigoletto in 2012, 2013’s hit production of Die Zauberflöte, and this past season’s critical favorite The Consul.

He served as cover conductor for over 25 productions, covering such notable conductors as Richard Bonynge, Richard Buckley, Peter Leonard, Stewart Robertson, Alberto Veronesi and Willie Anthony Waters. He served four seasons the company’s Education Manager, during which time Mr. Bisantz developed several new education initiatives, including a scholarship / mentoring program for Miami-Dade high school seniors interested in pursuing a career in the arts. 


The Voices of Stars & Distances


Edgar Miguel Abreu
Tenor Edgar Miguel Abréu debuts at Florida Grand Opera this season. Edgar serves as music director and pianist at Our Lady Queen of Heaven Catholic Church in North Lauderdale, FL and as director of the Teaching Outstanding Performers camp at Florida Atlantic University. He earned his Master of Music Degree in Vocal Performance from Florida International University and his bachelor’s degree from Florida Atlantic University. This season at FGO, Edgar will perform the roles of Ambrogio in Rossini’s The Barber of Seville and Flavio in Bellini’s Norma, and will study-cover the roles of Pollione in Norma and Walter in Weinberg’s The Passenger.


Daniel Bates
Tenor Daniel Bates returns to Florida Grand Opera this season for a second year in the company’s Young Artist Program. Last season on the FGO stage, he was seen as Goro in Madama Butterfly, Ferrando in Così fan tutte, and Nadir in Les pêcheurs de perles. Mr. Bates is a graduate of the San Francisco Conservatory of Music and Ithaca College. This season at FGO, he sings SS Man #3 in Weinberg’s The Passenger and Ernesto in select performances of Don Pasquale.


Scott Bracken-Tripp
Mr. Bracken-Tripp is an experienced recitalist and opera singer, and has extensive experience teaching students of all ages. He holds a Master of Music degree in voice performance, and currently teaches at Florida International University and at New World School of the Arts in Miami, FL. He is Director of Music at St. John's on the Lake United Methodist Church, the founding director of the Miami Beach Alliance Honor Chorale, and the president of the local South Florida NATS chapter.


Isaac Bray
Baritone Isaac Bray is a recent graduate of the Boston University Opera Institute, where he performed Don Giovanni (Don Giovanni) and Riolobo (Catán’s Florencia en el Amazonas) in 2014, Owen Wingrave (Britten’s Owen Wingrave) in 2013, and Barone Douphol (La traviata) and Des Grieux (Massenet’s Le portrait de Manon) in 2012. This past summer, Isaac returned to Central City Opera as an Apprentice Artist to sing the role of Sam (Trouble in Tahiti) and to cover the role of Joseph De Rocher (Heggie’s Dead Man Walking).


Amanda Crider
American mezzo-soprano Amanda Crider is quickly gaining recognition for her extraordinary musicality and assured dramatic presence. Recent engagements included joining New World Symphony for de Falla’s El amor brujo, the Louisiana Philharmonic for a Baroque Christmas, Carnegie Mellon Philharmonic for Mozart’s Requiem, and her role debut as Angelina in La Cenerentola with Opera Roanoke. Ms. Crider debuted with Florida Grand Opera in 2009 singing the role of Mallika in Lakmé, and went on to delight audiences as Cherubino in Le Nozze di Figaro.


Betsy Diaz
Cuban-American soprano Betsy Diaz recently completed her second season in FGO's Young Artist Program. She was featured on the FGO mainstage as Anna (Nabucco, 2014) and as The Foreign Woman (The Consul, 2015). Betsy has been a regional finalist with the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions, a semi-finalist in the Marcello Giordani International Voice Competition, and a prize winner in the Palm Beach Opera and Florida Suncoast Opera Guild competitions. She has performed with the Symphony of the Americas, Miami Symphony Orchestra, and the Concert Association of Florida.


Bob Dundas
Bob Dundas currently serves as the Interim Director of the School of Music, Associate Professor of Vocal Studies, and Director of Opera Theater. A native of Keene, New Hampshire, Professor Dundas completed his graduate studies in Voice and Opera at the University of Iowa. Professor Dundas remains active as a concert soloist and recitalist and has performed with the Bel Canto Society of Cape Cod, the Monomoy Chamber Music Series, the Miami Master Chorale, the Mondanock Chorus and Orchestra, the Imperial Symphony, and the Miami Bach Society.


Chance Eakin
Bass-baritone Chance Eakin’s recent roles include numerous credits with Florida Grand Opera, including The Official Registrar (Madama Butterfly, 2014), Mr. Kofner (The Consul, 2015), and the study cover of Don Alfonso (Così fan tutte, 2015). Originally from Central Texas, Chance received his Bachelor of Music Degree in Vocal Performance from Baylor University before pursuing his master’s degree at the University of Cincinnati College-Conservatory of Music. Most recently, he completed doctoral coursework at the University of Texas at Austin.


John J Fleming
John was heard for a number of years as a promotional voice for the AMERICAN MOVIE CLASSICS and the BRAVO television networks as well as ABC, ESPN, and CBS Sports. He has also voiced exhibits for New York’s MUSEUM of MODERN ART and the WHITNEY. He has recorded audio books for best-selling authors such as Danielle Steel, and for leading publishers Bantam, Doubleday, Dell and others. He has also appeared as an actor in theater, film and television.


Rebecca Henriques
Cuban-American soprano Rebecca Henriques is a former FGO Young Artist who has recently performed the roles of Lucy (The Telephone, 2014) and Despina (Così fan tutte, 2015) with Florida Grand Opera, Pamina (Die Zauberflöte) with Frost Opera Theater in 2013, Contessa Almaviva (Le Nozze di Figaro) with Frost Opera Theater in 2012, and Miss Wordsworth (Albert Herring) at the University of Illinois in 2010. She received the first prize in lyric singing at the Concorso di Escuzione Musicale in Matera, Italy in 2013 and an encouragement award at the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions in 2008.


Will Hughes
Baritone Will Hughes recently received his Master of Music Degree in Voice Performance and Pedagogy from Westminster Choir College in Princeton, New Jersey where he studied under Dr. Christopher Arneson. Will hails from Dallas, Texas and earned his Bachelor of Music Degree in Voice Performance from Wheaton College, where he was the recipient of the Ben Heppner Prize.


Carla Jablonski
Mezzo-soprano Carla Jablonski has sung with the Wolf Trap Opera Company, Opera Santa Barbara, Chautauqua Opera, Central City Opera and Manhattan Opera Studio. As a former member of Florida Grand Opera’s Young Artist Program, Carla was seen as Annina (La traviata) and Third Lady (Die Zauberflöte) in 2013. This past season, Carla joined the Metropolitan Opera as a chorus member (Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg), under the baton of James Levine. Carla received her master’s degree from the Juilliard School.


Laura Martinez Leon
Cuban soprano Laura Martinez León makes her Florida Grand Opera debut this season. She is currently completing coursework for a Master of Music Degree in Voice Performance at FIU. This season at FGO Laura study-covers Yvette in Weinberg’s The Passenger and Norina in Donizetti’s Don Pasquale, and can be seen in numerous regional outreach performances.


Eric McConnell
Eric J. McConnell, bass-baritone, recently received his Bachelor of Music degree in Classical Vocal Performance at the Frost School of Music at the University of Miami, studying with renowned bass-baritone Kevin Short. This summer, Mr. McConnell is at Seagle Music Colony in Schroon Lake, NY, where he will perform the role of Basilio (Il barbiere di Siviglia), as well as workshop the role of Elisha Fitzgibbon in Evan Mack's opera Roscoe. He will then move to Chicago, where he will begin study for his Master's Degree in Vocal Performance at Northwestern University, working under the esteemed pedagogue Stephen Smith.


Sarah Payne
Soprano Sarah Payne, a native of South Florida, makes her Florida Grand Opera debut this season. In 2014 she was named a finalist in the annual International Richard Strauss Competition. Sarah has also been named a regional finalist in the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions. She holds a bachelor’s degree in vocal performance from Florida International University. This season at FGO, she sings Clotilda in Bellini’s Norma and study-covers Marta in Weinberg’s The Passenger.


Kirsten Scott
Mezzo soprano Kirsten Scott recently made her debut with Florida Grand Opera this past season in the role of Vera Boronel (The Consul, 2015). In 2011 she performed as lead soloist in the world premiere of Illuminessence: Prayers for Peace, an oratorio commissioned by the Vatican commemorating 9/11. Ms. Scott has also performed as a mezzo soloist with the AIMS Orchestra in Graz, Austria and L’art du Chant Français for a concert series throughout southern France.


Riley Svatos
Riley Svatos is from Lake Andes, South Dakota and graduated with a Bachelor’s of Music Education from South Dakota State University in 2011. In 2012 she was the grand-prize winner of the Franco-American Vocal Academy Grand Concours de Chant and was awarded the Winston Scholarship from the National Society of Arts and Letters. She also won an encouragement award at the Indiana District of the Metropolitan Opera National Council auditions this season. In November 2013, Ms. Svatos made her FGO debut in the role of Helen Niles in Marvin David Levy’s Mourning Becomes Electra. She received her Master of Music degree from Indiana University.


Top of Page


About Florida Grand Opera

Florida Grand Opera (FGO), the oldest performing arts organization in Florida, celebrates its 74th year of continuously producing grand opera during the 2014-15 Season. The mainstage operas of the season include: Giacomo Puccini’s Madama Butterfly, November 15 – December 6; Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart’s Così fan tutte, January 24 – February 14; Georges Bizet’s The Pearl Fishers (Les pêcheurs de perles), February 28 – March 14; and Gian Carlo Menotti’s The Consul, May 9 – 16.
Founded in 1941 as Greater Miami Opera and later merging with The Opera Guild Inc. in 1994, FGO presents a mixture of standard repertoire and contemporary works as well as commissions and new productions – all featuring projected translations in English and Spanish. For more information, please visit www.FGO.org.


About the Patricia and Phillip Frost Museum of Science

The Patricia and Phillip Frost Museum of Science aims to make a difference in people’s lives by inspiring them to appreciate the impact that science and technology can have on every facet of our world. In 2016, Frost Science will continue to inspire visitors in a new state-of-the-art facility designed by Grimshaw Architects currently under construction at Museum Park, in the heart of downtown Miami. The museum will be structured around a lushly landscaped indoor and outdoor Living Core Aquarium of terrestrial and aquatic environments, featuring a Gulf Stream tank experience totaling over 500,000 gallons of salt water. The facility will also feature the state-of-the-art full dome Frost Planetarium, the Knight Learning Center, Innovation Center and Cafe, and an Exploration Center featuring permanent interactive exhibits: Feathers to the Stars and The River of Grass. The museum is accredited by the American Alliance of Museums, is an affiliate of the Smithsonian Institution and a member of the Association of Science and Technology Centers. The Patricia and Phillip Frost Museum of Science is funded with the support of Miami-Dade County Department of Cultural Affairs and Cultural Affairs Council, the Miami-Dade County Mayor and Board of County Commissioners. Learn more at www.frostscience.org.



The Frost Planetarium


Thanks to an additional $10 million gift from Patricia and Phillip Frost, visitors at Frost Science will be able to explore the universe, from the depths of space to the building blocks of the cosmos, at the state-of-the-art, 250-seat Frost Planetarium.

Longtime supporters of South Florida’s arts and culture, the Frosts had previously made a $35 million donation to name the Patricia and Phillip Frost Museum of Science. Now, they are helping to complete one of the world's most advanced planetariums. The Frost Planetarium will feature a high-resolution, 16-million-color, 8K projection system, surround sound and software that will support the latest immersive experiences and allow images and data from NASA (space), NOAA (weather), and the U.S. Geological Survey (land) to be projected on the dome.

With Frost Planetarium's raked stadium-style seating and a seamless screen tilted at 23.5 degrees to match the tilt of the Earth’s axis in space, visitors will be able to look forward, rather than up, for a comfortable and immersive viewing experience. Visitors will be able to travel to distant galaxies, tour our planet from space, dive deep into the Gulf Stream, explore the inside of the human brain or discover the new world of nanotechnology.

Live broadcasts from scientists in the field, spectacular laser light shows and visuals transmitted by space probes or orbiting satellites are among the Frost Planetarium's unique experiences for visitors. In addition, the Frost Planetarium will serve as a uniquely appealing function space for events such as conferences, presentations and award ceremonies.

Immersive environments are on the rise, and it is the Frost Planetarium’s purpose to open the doors of its dome to scientists, educators, and students to help them develop their own content, while contributing to their careers, and the furthering of the medium.

In keeping with the Frost Science commitment to become a world-renowned facility with school programs, live presentations, pre-rendered shows, public lectures, and performances, Frost Science staff, including Brooks Weisplat, VP of Technology, Dr. Jorge Perez-Gallego, Exhibition Developer, and Mark Bennett, Planetarium & Visitor Services Manager, recently attended the Immersive Media Entertainment, Research, Science & Arts 2015 International Summit in Denver, CO.

"Research shows that planetariums may be one of the best environments to be effectively introduced to astronomy, and the mysteries of the cosmos. But it does not stop there, as the Frost Planetarium will also take you on memorable journeys to the depths of the ocean and the wonders of the brain. The Frost Planetarium will be an unforgettable immersive experience set to strengthen the understanding of the world around us and inspire the next generation of scientists." Dr. Jorge Perez-Gallego, Astronomer and Exhibition Developer at the Patricia and Phillip Frost Museum of Science

Completing the Frost Planetarium Dome


With its high profile, easily visible location, the Frost Planetarium dome will be a distinctive highlight at Frost Science. This spring, the museum celebrated the completion of the enclosure for its digital dome, a major construction milestone.

Completion of the dome was a carefully orchestrated project that took almost three weeks to complete under the direction of Skanska USA and Hill International. The operation began with erecting a massive, 50-foot tall center shoring tower and setting a precast dome cap. Then, construction crews installed the 54 concrete panels that make up the self-supporting planetarium dome. The panels were installed opposite one another in a counter-clockwise rotation to avoid lateral load on the dome capstone – the top center portion, 30 feet in diameter, which anchors all of the panels.

Each concrete panel measures approximately 48 feet from base to top, is roughly 9 feet wide at the base and tapers to approximately 3 feet at the top, where the panels meet the capstone. The total weight of all pieces of the dome exceeds 1.6 million pounds.
Top of Page

Frequently Asked Questions

There was an error with my contribution. What happened?

Please refer to this article on common contribution errors and steps to resolve: Common Contribution Errors.


When will my Stars & Distances CD ship?

FGO will personally ship all Stars & Distances CDs at the completion of the campaign page. Funders will receive their unautographed CD within a month. Funders who chose the autographed CD will receive theirs by the end of 2015.


Where does the Stars & Distances CD ship?

FGO will ship all perks to all 50 states, as well as internationally. Please note that shipment to an international address may further delay the fulfillment of your perk.


Will additional copies of this recording be available for purchase?

Yes! We fully intend to sell copies of Stars & Distances upon completion of this campaign. Please check our “Updates” page for additional information as it arrives.


When will the Frost Science planetarium be open to the public?

The Patricia and Phillip Frost Museum of Science will be open to the general public in 2016.


How did you choose your singers for this recording?

Ten out of the 16 voices needed for Stars & Distances were performed by Florida Grand Opera’s Young Artists, who perform all of the company’s outreach programs throughout the season.

The remaining six voices were found through our local network of contacts. Many of these students were referred to by their teachers, or, as with the case with Bob Dundas, are voice teachers themselves!


Who did your movie?

This movie was shot by PARMA Records. They are terrific!


For the “Hard Hat Planetarium Tour,” can I bring a guest?

Yes, for each individual who claims this perk, we are allowing him/her to bring one guest to accompany them.


What if I am not available to attend the guided tour?

We will be contacting each of the individuals who chose this perk individually to determine a mutually-agreeable time to host this tour. If you are unable to make this date, we will contact you to find a suitable replacement tour/perk.


If I have questions, how can I reach your team?

Please read through the FAQ first to find your answer. We are receiving a lot of special requests, and are responding as fast as possible!

For questions related to the Indiegogo campaign, you can contact support@indiegogo.com.

For all other questions regarding Stars & Distances, please contact pr@fgo.org.

Top of Page

Pagina En Espanol


El Proyecto:

Grabar una nueva e innovadora composición, Stars & Distances de Fredrick Kaufman, la cual servirá como una de las bandas sonoras oficiales para el nuevo Frost Planetarium, en el Patricia and Philip Frost Museum of Science en el Museum Park de downtown Miami.

Nuestra Historia:

En el verano de 2014, el director Andrew Bisantz se acercó a la Directora General y CEO de FGO con la propuesta para un Proyecto: grabar la innovadora composición Stars & Distances para que esta pudiera ser usada como una de las bandas sonoras oficiales del nuevo planetario.

Con la ayuda de Bisantz, el compositor Fredrick Kaufman, y Frost Science, FGO pudo reunir a un equipo entusiasta para dar vida a este proyecto. Para principios de otoño de 2014, los cantantes estaban preparados, los vuelos de la compañía de grabación estaban reservados, y había un gran interés por parte de donantes que buscaban financiar el proyecto.


¿Por qué los necesitamos a USTEDES?

Al iniciar el proceso de grabación, estas donaciones no se concretaron. Aunque FGO logró aportar los recursos suficientes para pagar la tarifa inicial de grabación, el proyecto fue suspendido temporalmente. 

Necesitamos de su ayuda para financiar la banda sonora para el nuevo Frost Planetarium de Miami en el Patricia and Philip Frost Museum of Science.



Desglose Del Presupuesto


Acerca de Stars & Distances:

Stars and Distances es una obra de 18 minutos para un ensamble vocal de 16 voces. La pieza fue conceptualizada en 1976, completada en 1982, y estrenada con gran éxito en 1986 por el Pacific Lutheran University Chorus. Desde ese entonces, la pieza fue revisada en anticipación a este proyecto.

Kaufman habla sobre Stars and Distances:
Stars & Distances llegó a mí mientras estaba recostado una noche en Hyde Park, en Londres, mirando hacia el Cosmos, tratando de imaginar cómo se escucharía ese sobrecogedor ensamble de luceros si emitieran un sonido. Al día siguiente, volví con un telescopio y gráficas que tomé prestadas del departamento de astronomía de la Universidad de Londres.

… Decidí tratar de identificar 15 de las estrellas más brillantes en el cielo esa noche. Al investigar esas estrellas, descubrí que cada una de ellas tenía una característica individual fascinante… Todas ellas eran considerablemente más grandes que nuestro sol y muchas de ellas, más poderosas.

Entonces, empecé a trabajar en la composición.

Como explica Kaufman, esas 15 estrellas sirvieron como el elemento catalizador de esta composición. La pieza está dividida en 15 partes, cada una marcada por las características individuales fascinantes de las estrellas que lo inspiraron. Estas características incluyen la calidad del sonido, volumen, complejidad, y energía transmitida por el ensamble de 16 voces.

A lo largo de la composición podemos escuchar la esencia de lecturas científicas y poéticas ondulantes, a cargo de los actores John Fleming y Karen Fuller, extraídas de escritos brillantes de científicos y poetas de renombre. Todos estos relacionados con el tema de Estrellas y Distancias ("Stars and Distances"). 

Top of Page

The Project -- Budget -- About Stars & Distances -- The Team -- FAQ -- 




The Project:To record an innovative, new composition, Stars & Distances by Fredrick Kaufman, which will serve as a special soundtrack for Miami’s new Frost Planetarium at the Patricia and Phillip
Frost Museum of Science in downtown Miami's Museum Park.
Our Story:
 In the summer of 2014, FGO’s General Director & CEO, Susan T. Danis was approached by conductor Andrew Bisantz with a project proposal: to record composer Fredrick Kaufman's innovative composition Stars & Distances so it could become a special soundtrack to the new Frost Planetarium.With assistance from Bisantz, composer Fredrick Kaufman, and Frost Science, FGO was able to pull together an enthusiastic team to get this project off the ground. By early fall of 2014, singers had been arranged, a recording company was scheduled to fly down, and donations to fund the project were lining up.
Why We Need YOU!

Just as the recording process began, these anticipated donations did not come through. Although FGO was able to put up enough money to fund the initial recording fees, the project has since been put on
hold.
We need you to help fund this special soundtrack to Miami’s new Frost Planetarium at the Patricia and Phillip Frost Museum of Science.


Budget Breakdown



About Stars
& Distances: 
Stars and Distances is an 18’ work for a 16-voice vocal chamber ensemble. The piece, first conceptualized in 1976, was completed in 1982 and premiered to “great success” in 1986 by the Pacific Lutheran University Chorus. The piece has since been revised in anticipation for this project. 
Kaufman on Stars and Distances:


Stars & Distances came to me as I lay on my back one night in Hyde Park, London, staring up at the Cosmos trying to imagine what overwhelming assemblage of specs would sound like if they indeed had a sound. The next day I came back with a telescope and charts I had borrowed from the University of London Astronomy Department.

… I decided to try to identify 15
of the brightest stars in the sky that night.
As I researched those stars I
discovered that each one of them had an individual fascinating characteristic …
All of them are considerably larger than our sun and many, much more powerful. 
I then set out to work writing the composition.
As Kaufman explains, those 15 stars served as the catalyst
for his composition. The piece is divided into 15 parts, each marked by the “individual
fascinating” characteristics of the stars which inspired him. Such
characteristics include sound quality, volume, complexity, and energy delivered
by the 16-voice ensemble. 
Throughout the composition we hear essences of undulating scientific and poetry readings by actors John Fleming and Karen Fuller drawn from the brilliant writings of renowned scientists and poets, all related to the subject, Stars and Distances. 
 Top of Page

The Stars & Distances Team


Fredrick Kaufman, composer Fredrick Kaufman (b. 1936) is the composer of over one hundred and thirty compositions that have been performed worldwide by orchestras such as the Warsaw Philharmonic, Israel Philharmonic, Czech Radio Orchestra, Lithuanian Philharmonic, Czech National Symphony Orchestra, Jerusalem Symphony, Instrumental Ensemble of Grenoble, London Sinfonietta, Orchestra Novi Musici, Dominican Republic National Orchestra, National Orchestra of Brazil, Los Angeles Philharmonic, New World Symphony the Pittsburgh Symphony orchestras, and Florida Grand Opera. Kaufman is a former Fulbright Scholar, and recipient honors and fellowships from the Endowment of the Arts, the Rockefeller, Guggenheim and Ford Foundations.
Twice nominated for a Pulitzer Prize, Kaufman's Holocaust composition Kaddish, which Bernard Holland of The New York Times described as "having the most expressive writing for strings to be heard today," has been performed over 100 times in the major concert halls of Europe, Eastern Europe, Scandinavia, Israel, South America, Asia and throughout the United States. His works have received prizes at international competitions and have been performed throughout the world at major music festivals. Israeli television has paid tribute to him as a composer in the thirty minute documentary film Fredrick Kaufman-Life of an Artist. 
Critics from the New York Times, Newark Star-Ledger, Philadelphia Inquirer, Miami Herald, Jerusalem Post, London Times, Perpignan Independent have described Kaufman's music as “striking…individual…an interesting combination of overwhelming pathos and infectious joy…brought one into the realm of musical genius.”
His Kaminarimon (for Taiko drums and Flamenco dance) has been called "remarkable" and "stunning" and was voted as the number one classical composition of 2002 and "the most imaginative new work of the year" by music critic James Roos of The Miami Herald.  String Quartet #6, The Urban was called "stunning" by The New Yorker magazine. The Quartet was nominated by Lukas Foss in 2007 for a Pulitzer Prize.
Kaufman is very excited about his new association with Florida Grand Opera and feels that their spectacular performance of his Stars & Distances will be acclaimed by the public and critics alike.



Andrew Bisantz, conductorA versatile musician acknowledged for his passionate and commanding leadership from the podium, the exciting young American conductor Andrew Bisantz is quickly building an impressive roster of credits at leading national orchestras and opera companies throughout the country. For his debut with Boston Lyric Opera leading The Turn of the Screw, the Boston Globe selected it as one of the ten top Boston classical music events of 2010. He subsequently returned for productions of Tosca and Madama Butterfly.Mr. Bisantz joined the music staff of Florida Grand Opera in 2002, first as Assistant Conductor, then as Resident Conductor. He made his FGO mainstage debut in the 2005-06 season, conducting Bizet’s Carmen for the company’s historic final performances at Miami-Dade County Auditorium, and he returned as the 2006-07 Henry C. Clark Conductor to conduct performances of Manon Lescaut. Additionally, he has conducted La cenerentola and La bohème for FGO. 
In recent seasons he’s led acclaimed productions of Don Giovanni (one of South Florida Classical Review’s Ten Best Performances of 2011), Rigoletto in 2012, 2013’s hit production of Die Zauberflöte, and this past season’s critical favorite The Consul.
He served as cover conductor for over 25 productions, covering such notable conductors as Richard Bonynge, Richard Buckley, Peter Leonard, Stewart Robertson, Alberto Veronesi and Willie Anthony Waters. He served four seasons the company’s Education Manager, during which time Mr. Bisantz developed several new education initiatives, including a scholarship / mentoring program for Miami-Dade high school seniors interested in pursuing a career in the arts. 
 The Voices of Stars & Distances  

Edgar Miguel Abreu 
Tenor Edgar Miguel Abréu debuts at Florida Grand Opera this season. Edgar serves as music director and pianist at Our Lady Queen of Heaven Catholic Church in North Lauderdale, FL and as director of the Teaching Outstanding Performers camp at Florida Atlantic University. He earned his Master of Music Degree in Vocal Performance from Florida International University and his bachelor’s degree from Florida Atlantic University. This season at FGO, Edgar will perform the roles of Ambrogio in Rossini’s The Barber of Seville and Flavio in Bellini’s Norma, and will study-cover the roles of Pollione in Norma and Walter in Weinberg’s The Passenger. 

Daniel Bates 
Tenor Daniel Bates returns to Florida Grand Opera this season for a second year in the company’s Young Artist Program. Last season on the FGO stage, he was seen as Goro in Madama Butterfly, Ferrando in Così fan tutte, and Nadir in Les pêcheurs de perles. Mr. Bates is a graduate of the San Francisco Conservatory of Music and Ithaca College. This season at FGO, he sings SS Man #3 in Weinberg’s The Passenger and Ernesto in select performances of Don Pasquale. 

Scott Bracken-Tripp
Mr. Bracken-Tripp is an experienced recitalist and opera singer, and has extensive experience teaching students of all ages. He holds a Master of Music degree in voice performance, and currently teaches at Florida International University and at New World School of the Arts in Miami, FL. He is Director of Music at St. John's on the Lake United Methodist Church, the founding director of the Miami Beach Alliance Honor Chorale, and the president of the local South Florida NATS chapter. 

Isaac Bray
Baritone Isaac Bray is a recent graduate of the Boston University Opera Institute, where he performed Don Giovanni (Don Giovanni) and Riolobo (Catán’s Florencia en el Amazonas) in 2014, Owen Wingrave (Britten’s Owen Wingrave) in 2013, and Barone Douphol (La traviata) and Des Grieux (Massenet’s Le portrait de Manon) in 2012. This past summer, Isaac returned to Central City Opera as an Apprentice Artist to sing the role of Sam (Trouble in Tahiti) and to cover the role of Joseph De Rocher (Heggie’s Dead Man Walking). 

Amanda Crider
American mezzo-soprano Amanda Crider is quickly gaining recognition for her extraordinary musicality and assured dramatic presence. Recent engagements included joining New World Symphony for de Falla’s El amor brujo, the Louisiana Philharmonic for a Baroque Christmas, Carnegie Mellon Philharmonic for Mozart’s Requiem, and her role debut as Angelina in La Cenerentola with Opera Roanoke. Ms. Crider debuted with Florida Grand Opera in 2009 singing the role of Mallika in Lakmé, and went on to delight audiences as Cherubino in Le Nozze di Figaro. 

Betsy Diaz
Cuban-American soprano Betsy Diaz recently completed her second season in FGO's Young Artist Program. She was featured on the FGO mainstage as Anna (Nabucco, 2014) and as The Foreign Woman (The Consul, 2015). Betsy has been a regional finalist with the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions, a semi-finalist in the Marcello Giordani International Voice Competition, and a prize winner in the Palm Beach Opera and Florida Suncoast Opera Guild competitions. She has performed with the Symphony of the Americas, Miami Symphony Orchestra, and the Concert Association of Florida.

Bob Dundas
Bob Dundas currently serves as the Interim Director  of the School of Music, Associate Professor of Vocal Studies, and Director of Opera Theater. A native of Keene, New Hampshire, Professor Dundas completed his graduate studies in Voice and Opera at the University of Iowa. Professor Dundas remains active as a concert soloist and recitalist and has performed with the Bel Canto Society of Cape Cod, the Monomoy Chamber Music Series, the Miami Master Chorale, the Mondanock Chorus and Orchestra, the Imperial Symphony, and the Miami Bach Society. 

Chance Eakin
Bass-baritone Chance Eakin’s recent roles include numerous credits with Florida Grand Opera, including The Official Registrar (Madama Butterfly, 2014), Mr. Kofner (The Consul, 2015), and the study cover of Don Alfonso (Così fan tutte, 2015). Originally from Central Texas, Chance received his Bachelor of Music Degree in Vocal Performance from Baylor University before pursuing his master’s degree at the University of Cincinnati College-Conservatory of Music. Most recently, he completed doctoral coursework at the University of Texas at Austin.

John J Fleming

John was heard for a number of years as a promotional voice for the AMERICAN MOVIE CLASSICS and the BRAVO television networks as well as ABC, ESPN, and CBS Sports. He has also voiced exhibits for New York’s MUSEUM of MODERN ART and the WHITNEY.  He has recorded audio books for best-selling authors such as Danielle Steel, and for leading publishers Bantam, Doubleday, Dell and others. He has also appeared as an actor in theater, film and television. 

Rebecca Henriques
Cuban-American soprano Rebecca Henriques is a former FGO Young Artist who has recently performed the roles of Lucy (The Telephone, 2014) and Despina (Così fan tutte, 2015) with Florida Grand Opera, Pamina (Die Zauberflöte) with Frost Opera Theater in 2013, Contessa Almaviva (Le Nozze di Figaro) with Frost Opera Theater in 2012, and Miss Wordsworth (Albert Herring) at the University of Illinois in 2010. She received the first prize in lyric singing at the Concorso di Escuzione Musicale in Matera, Italy in 2013 and an encouragement award at the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions in 2008.

Will Hughes
Baritone Will Hughes recently received his Master of Music Degree in Voice Performance and Pedagogy from Westminster Choir College in Princeton, New Jersey where he studied under Dr. Christopher Arneson. Will hails from Dallas, Texas and earned his Bachelor of Music Degree in Voice Performance from Wheaton College, where he was the recipient of the Ben Heppner Prize.

Carla Jablonski
Mezzo-soprano Carla Jablonski has sung with the Wolf Trap Opera Company, Opera Santa Barbara, Chautauqua Opera, Central City Opera and Manhattan Opera Studio. As a former member of Florida Grand Opera’s Young Artist Program, Carla was seen as Annina (La traviata) and Third Lady (Die Zauberflöte) in 2013. This past season, Carla joined the Metropolitan Opera as a chorus member (Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg), under the baton of James Levine. Carla received her master’s degree from the Juilliard School.

Laura Martinez Leon 
Cuban soprano Laura Martinez León makes her Florida Grand Opera debut this season. She is currently completing coursework for a Master of Music Degree in Voice Performance at FIU. This season at FGO Laura study-covers Yvette in Weinberg’s The Passenger and Norina in Donizetti’s Don Pasquale, and can be seen in numerous regional outreach performances.

Eric McConnell
Eric J. McConnell, bass-baritone, recently received his Bachelor of Music degree in Classical Vocal Performance at the Frost School of Music at the University of Miami, studying with renowned bass-baritone Kevin Short. This summer, Mr. McConnell is at Seagle Music Colony in Schroon Lake, NY, where he will perform the role of Basilio (Il barbiere di Siviglia), as well as workshop the role of Elisha Fitzgibbon in Evan Mack's opera Roscoe. He will then move to Chicago, where he will begin study for his Master's Degree in Vocal Performance at Northwestern University, working under the esteemed pedagogue Stephen Smith.

Sarah Payne
Soprano Sarah Payne, a native of South Florida, makes her Florida Grand Opera debut this season. In 2014 she was named a finalist in the annual International Richard Strauss Competition. Sarah has also been named a regional finalist in the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions. She holds a bachelor’s degree in vocal performance from Florida International University. This season at FGO, she sings Clotilda in Bellini’s Norma and study-covers Marta in Weinberg’s The Passenger.

Kirsten Scott
Mezzo soprano Kirsten Scott recently made her debut with Florida Grand Opera this past season in the role of Vera Boronel (The Consul, 2015). In 2011 she performed as lead soloist in the world premiere of Illuminessence: Prayers for Peace, an oratorio commissioned by the Vatican commemorating 9/11. Ms. Scott has also performed as a mezzo soloist with the AIMS Orchestra in Graz, Austria and L’art du Chant Français for a concert series throughout southern France.

Riley Svatos
Riley Svatos is from Lake Andes, South Dakota and graduated with a Bachelor’s of Music Education from South Dakota State University in 2011. In 2012 she was the grand-prize winner of the Franco-American Vocal Academy Grand Concours de Chant and was awarded the Winston Scholarship from the National Society of Arts and Letters. She also won an encouragement award at the Indiana District of the Metropolitan Opera National Council auditions this season. In November 2013, Ms. Svatos made her FGO debut in the role of Helen Niles in Marvin David Levy’s Mourning Becomes Electra. She received her Master of Music degree from Indiana University.  Top of PageAbout Florida Grand Opera


Florida Grand Opera (FGO), the oldest performing arts organization in Florida, celebrates its 74th year of continuously producing grand opera during the 2014-15 Season. The mainstage operas of the season include: Giacomo Puccini’s Madama Butterfly, November 15 – December 6; Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart’s Così fan tutte, January 24 – February 14; Georges Bizet’s The Pearl Fishers (Les pêcheurs de perles), February 28 – March 14; and Gian Carlo Menotti’s The Consul, May 9 – 16.

Founded in 1941 as Greater Miami Opera and later merging with The Opera Guild Inc. in 1994, FGO presents a mixture of standard repertoire and contemporary works as well as commissions and new productions – all featuring projected translations in English and Spanish. For more information, please visit www.FGO.org. About the Patricia and Phillip Frost Museum of Science

The Patricia and Phillip Frost Museum of Science aims to make a difference in people’s lives by inspiring them to appreciate the impact that science and technology can have on every facet of our world. In 2016, Frost Science will continue to inspire visitors in a new state-of-the-art facility designed by Grimshaw Architects currently under construction at Museum Park, in the heart of downtown Miami. The museum will be structured around a lushly landscaped indoor and outdoor Living Core Aquarium of terrestrial and aquatic environments, featuring a Gulf Stream tank experience totaling over 500,000 gallons of salt water. The facility will also feature the state-of-the-art full dome Frost Planetarium, the Knight Learning Center, Innovation Center and Cafe, and an Exploration Center featuring permanent interactive exhibits: Feathers to the Stars and The River of Grass. The museum is accredited by the American Alliance of Museums, is an affiliate of the Smithsonian Institution and a member of the Association of Science and Technology Centers. The Patricia and Phillip Frost Museum of Science is funded with the support of Miami-Dade County Department of Cultural Affairs and Cultural Affairs Council, the Miami-Dade County Mayor and Board of County Commissioners. Learn more at www.frostscience.org.
The Frost Planetarium 

Thanks to an additional $10 million gift from Patricia and Phillip Frost, visitors at Frost Science will be able to explore the universe, from the depths of space to the building blocks of the cosmos, at the state-of-the-art, 250-seat Frost Planetarium.
 
Longtime supporters of South Florida’s arts and culture, the Frosts had previously made a $35 million donation to name the Patricia and Phillip Frost Museum of Science. Now, they are helping to complete one of the world's most advanced planetariums. The Frost Planetarium will feature a high-resolution, 16-million-color, 8K projection system, surround sound and software that will support the latest immersive experiences and allow images and data from NASA (space), NOAA (weather), and the U.S. Geological Survey (land) to be projected on the dome.
 
With Frost Planetarium's raked stadium-style seating and a seamless screen tilted at 23.5 degrees to match the tilt of the Earth’s axis in space, visitors will be able to look forward, rather than up, for a comfortable and immersive viewing experience. Visitors will be able to travel to distant galaxies, tour our planet from space, dive deep into the Gulf Stream, explore the inside of the human brain or discover the new world of nanotechnology. 
 
Live broadcasts from scientists in the field, spectacular laser light shows and visuals transmitted by space probes or orbiting satellites are among the Frost Planetarium's unique experiences for visitors. In addition, the Frost Planetarium will serve as a uniquely appealing function space for events such as conferences, presentations and award ceremonies.
 
Immersive environments are on the rise, and it is the Frost Planetarium’s purpose to open the doors of its dome to scientists, educators, and students to help them develop their own content, while contributing to their careers, and the furthering of the medium. 
 
In keeping with the Frost Science commitment to become a world-renowned facility with school programs, live presentations, pre-rendered shows, public lectures, and performances, Frost Science staff, including Brooks Weisplat, VP of Technology, Dr. Jorge Perez-Gallego, Exhibition Developer, and Mark Bennett, Planetarium & Visitor Services Manager, recently attended the Immersive Media Entertainment, Research, Science & Arts 2015 International Summit in Denver, CO.
 
"Research shows that planetariums may be one of the best environments to be effectively introduced to astronomy, and the mysteries of the cosmos. But it does not stop there, as the Frost Planetarium will also take you on memorable journeys to the depths of the ocean and the wonders of the brain. The Frost Planetarium will be an unforgettable immersive experience set to strengthen the understanding of the world around us and inspire the next generation of scientists."
Dr. Jorge Perez-Gallego, Astronomer and Exhibition Developer at the Patricia and Phillip Frost Museum of Science
Completing the Frost Planetarium Dome 
 
With its high profile, easily visible location, the Frost Planetarium dome will be a distinctive highlight at Frost Science. This spring, the museum celebrated the completion of the enclosure for its digital dome, a major construction milestone.  
 
Completion of the dome was a carefully orchestrated project that took almost three weeks to complete under the direction of Skanska USA and Hill International. The operation began with erecting a massive, 50-foot tall center shoring tower and setting a precast dome cap. Then, construction crews installed the 54 concrete panels that make up the self-supporting planetarium dome. The panels were installed opposite one another in a counter-clockwise rotation to avoid lateral load on the dome capstone – the top center portion, 30 feet in diameter, which anchors all of the panels.
 
Each concrete panel measures approximately 48 feet from base to top, is roughly 9 feet wide at the base and tapers to approximately 3 feet at the top, where the panels meet the capstone. The total weight of all pieces of the dome exceeds 1.6 million pounds.Top of Page


Frequently Asked Questions
There was an error with my
contribution. What happened?
Please refer to this article on
common contribution errors and steps to resolve: Common Contribution Errors.

When will my Stars & Distances
CD ship?
FGO will personally ship all Stars
& Distances CDs at the completion of the campaign page. Funders will
receive their unautographed CD within
a month. Funders who chose the autographed
CD will receive theirs by the end of 2015.

Where does the Stars &
Distances CD ship?
FGO will ship all perks to all 50
states, as well as internationally. Please note that shipment to an
international address may further delay the fulfillment of your perk.

Will additional copies of this
recording be available for purchase? 
Yes! We fully intend to sell copies
of Stars & Distances upon completion
of this campaign. Please check our “Updates” page for additional information as
it arrives.

When will the Frost Science
planetarium be open to the public?
The Patricia and Phillip Frost
Museum of Science will be open to the general public in 2016.

How did you choose your singers for
this recording?
Ten out of the 16 voices needed for
Stars & Distances were performed by Florida Grand Opera’s Young Artists,
who perform all of the company’s outreach programs throughout the season.
The remaining six voices were found
through our local network of contacts. Many of these students were referred to
by their teachers, or, as with the case with Bob Dundas, are voice teachers
themselves!

Who did your movie? 
This movie was shot by PARMA
Records. They are terrific!

For the “Hard Hat Planetarium Tour,”
can I bring a guest?
Yes, for each individual who claims
this perk, we are allowing him/her to bring one guest to accompany them.

What if I am not available to
attend the guided tour?
We will be contacting each of the
individuals who chose this perk individually to determine a mutually-agreeable
time to host this tour. If you are unable to make this date, we will contact
you to find a suitable replacement tour/perk.

If I have questions, how can I
reach your team? 
Please read through the FAQ first
to find your answer. We are receiving a lot of special requests, and are
responding as fast as possible! 
For questions related to the
Indiegogo campaign, you can contact support@indiegogo.com. 
For all other questions regarding
Stars & Distances, please contact pr@fgo.org.
Top of Page

The music is done, and ready to go! By pre-ordering the album and perks here, you help us press and release the album with high quality CDs, packaging, and artwork!

We've put 2 years of writing, and nearly 80 hours of studio time (plus a lot of money) into making this album. We are so proud of what we have accomplished. Help us put the finishing touches on and get it out to you by pre-ordering here today!
