story:
Short Summary

I am a queer, multicultural, contemplative, cross-genre artist/songwriter who has been figuring things out musically since my first showcase of original and cover songs in 1993. I am from the Seattle area and currently live in Boulder, Colorado finishing a graduate degree at Naropa University in Somatic Counseling and Dance/Movement Therapy. Music-making and performing is an integral part of my life, a way to channel and to challenge what I know and want to know about myself, relationships, and the world. I headlined MainStage at Seattle Pride in 2003 with my single, "Gay Marriage Song" and released it as an acoustic piano/vocal on CD Baby in 2013. My newest album, Home, is my first studio recorded with collaborating musicians in jazz, folk, rock, and a cappella styles. Some people rate me as a "balladeer." I don't know what to call myself. But, I have valued connecting with fans who have over and over again come to see my shows, buy my music on and offline, and who have shared their stories, their hopes and dreams, a foundation for what my songs are about and how they come to be. Home, fills a unique space in music-making legacies. It is a part of a stream of performance artistry and songwriting in which generations of artists of which I am a part can find encouragement and support. You are a part of our artlovelegacies.

A little sample of my live work can be found at http://youtube.com/brianottokimmel. You can also visit my website that I am in the process of updating to reflect the fuller brand of my work and the upcoming 2017 release of, Home, at http://www.briankimmel.com.

What We Need

  • My goal of $3200 is the minimum I would need to finish my album in the studio. The funds will go towards paying my recording engineer, Jake, for the work we do in the studio laying music tracks, editing, mixing, and mastering which altogether is around $2000, paying musicians around $300, and administrative costs like copyrights, CD production, and publishing, around $550, and the cost of running a campaign including sending perks $350.
  • Every bit of the funds will go towards finishing the album in the studio. I have already contributed time and money to this project. If I reach the entire goal, the album will be completed in entirety and will help me pay and prevent me from going into debt. The completed album like my prior albums and to a greater degree will be a source of revenue and promotion for this and future projects. 
  • Future campaigns may include raising support and funds for performances this spring and summer in the United States and abroad, and future production needs not covered by this campaign like production and release of singles and B-sides that will not be on Home, but were recorded during the project. I would also like to compile and publish manuscripts of the music from Home so that those who read music can play along and/or make covers of my songs, another possible source of revenue for me. A second and third campaign of $2300 - $3200 for these expenses may be up and coming. 
  • Our agenda for the project is as follows: June 2016 finish laying tracks for album, July 2016 Finish studio work with Jake through mixing and mastering, August 2016 perform and promote,  September 2016 publish and send for manufacturing in time for Do It Yourself Musician's Conference in Chicago, October 2016, send gifts, November release pre-sale online at iTunes and CDBaby, Jan - February 2017 performances, March 2017 official release concert in Boulder, Summer 2017 tentative tour performances in Europe.

What You Will Get

This is my favorite part, what you will receive in time for Fall and Winter Holidays and Celebrations. A chance to share the beauty of our collective voices that helped craft and deliver these songs home. 

  • $5 Home Is Closer Than You Think - A download of my title track, "Home Is Closer Than You Think."
  •  $32 Home - A digital pre-sale album of Home with digital liner notes. $104 True Community Builder - A digital pre-sale album and two hard-copies of Home by mail with liner-notes. 
  • $257 Our Love's As Big As An Ocean - A digital pre-sale album and an option of a hard-copy album with signed liner notes, plus a bonus video of me singing a song I wrote just for you that you can share with everyone you know. 
  • $500 I'll Sing For You - Nothing says thank you more than a live concert with me singing favorites and covers from Home. Additional travel expenses may apply. Includes a digital copy of album and one autographed hard copy with autographed liner notes.

The Impact

  • What fans often say is that whenever they hear my music, they feel happy. My music and performance helps their heart open, helps them touch feelings, love, warmth, memories that they have not been in touch with for a long time and did not know they have missed. Although I love being a musician and an artist, I believe my main work is as a listener. I listen to the stories that people share with me. I listen to prayers, dreams, hopes, desires of those in my life, and that's what I end up writing about. My songs are like prayers. They are ways to rekindle and to remember what matters most. And I believe that music-making is an art-form that transcends culture and yet speaks in culturally specific ways. But rhythm and song is a part of the earth, is part of every living being. 
  • I have been doing it myself and raising money for albums and performances for nearly twenty-five years. Fans have contributed to my music projects and travels by buying my music online and at shows, coming out to hear me play locally, booking house concerts and benefit performances, and some who have left me money in their wills and trusts.
  • Honestly, I have not ever done music alone, because fans have been with me every step of the way. Every time I have written a song, it has been my fans in the front, middle, and back rows who have time and time again been there to experience the music first hand. I have a folder of letters I have received and an inbox full of messages from participant-audiences who have gifted me with their responses to my work, and the stories that brought them to my music, and what they remembered when they experienced it.

Risks & Challenges

For me, the scariest challenge is not having faith enough in myself to continue this project to the end. Money means a lot, because it gets people in the space with me, turns on the power in the studio, and helps sign me up for distribution that will help get the music and my message out into the world, to people who may need it. I think of the many young artists out there who like me started out with people saying they couldn't do what they wanted to do with their music, or their art, or that they had to sacrifice some part of themselves in order to get noticed. That way doesn't cut it for me anymore, and I have endeavored with, Home, and my year-long artlovelegacies project to do music that feels like home. I continue finding myself through performance, lyrics, rhythm, and melody. And I continue to challenge myself even when a voice in the back of my head might say: "You can't do that." I hear you, voice, now watch me! 

I have been in the business of music-making long enough to know that being authentic makes the best kind of art, the art that feels good when it is delivered. It has taken a whole lot of space, healing, time, and loving community for me to find a voice that feels like home. I will never forget the legacies of which I am a part. The many patrons of my art. To you, a multitude of gratitude.

Other Ways You Can Help

The best way you can be of help is to breathe and smile while visiting this campaign page. And if you like it and want to be of help but cannot contribute financially, please do share this page with friends. Please ask them to give because it is important to you, to me, and I believe to spreading love out into this world. Let your friends, family, and co-workers know how you were impacted by reading my story or watching my video.

I headlined MainStage at Seattle Pride in 2003 with my single, "Gay Marriage Song" and released it as an acoustic piano/vocal on CD Baby in 2013. My newest album, Home, is my first studio recorded with collaborating musicians in jazz, folk, rock, and a cappella styles. Some people rate me as a "balladeer." I don't know what to call myself. But, I have valued connecting with fans who have over and over again come to see my shows, buy my music on and offline, and who have shared their stories, their hopes and dreams, a foundation for what my songs are about and how they come to be. Home, fills a unique space in music-making legacies. It is a part of a stream of performance artistry and songwriting in which generations of artists of which I am a part can find encouragement and support. You are a part of our artlovelegacies.
A little sample of my live work can be found at http://youtube.com/brianottokimmel. You can also visit my website that I am in the process of updating to reflect the fuller brand of my work and the upcoming 2017 release of, Home, at http://www.briankimmel.com.

   What We Need  My goal of $3200 is the minimum I would need to finish my album in the studio. The funds will go towards paying my recording engineer, Jake, for the work we do in the studio laying music tracks, editing, mixing, and mastering which altogether is around $2000, paying musicians around $300, and administrative costs like copyrights, CD production, and publishing, around $550, and the cost of running a campaign including sending perks $350.
Every bit of the funds will go towards finishing the album in the studio. I have already contributed time and money to this project. If I reach the entire goal, the album will be completed in entirety and will help me pay and prevent me from going into debt. The completed album like my prior albums and to a greater degree will be a source of revenue and promotion for this and future projects. 
Future campaigns may include raising support and funds for performances this spring and summer in the United States and abroad, and future production needs not covered by this campaign like production and release of singles and B-sides that will not be on Home, but were recorded during the project. I would also like to compile and publish manuscripts of the music from Home so that those who read music can play along and/or make covers of my songs, another possible source of revenue for me. A second and third campaign of $2300 - $3200 for these expenses may be up and coming. 
Our agenda for the project is as follows: June 2016 finish laying tracks for album, July 2016 Finish studio work with Jake through mixing and mastering, August 2016 perform and promote,  September 2016 publish and send for manufacturing in time for Do It Yourself Musician's Conference in Chicago, October 2016, send gifts, November release pre-sale online at iTunes and CDBaby, Jan - February 2017 performances, March 2017 official release concert in Boulder, Summer 2017 tentative tour performances in Europe.
    

What You Will Get
This is my favorite part, what you will receive in time for Fall and Winter Holidays and Celebrations. A chance to share the beauty of our collective voices that helped craft and deliver these songs home. 

$5 Home Is Closer Than You Think - A download of my title track, "Home Is Closer Than You Think."

 $32 Home - A digital pre-sale album of Home with digital liner notes. $104 True Community Builder - A digital pre-sale album and two hard-copies of Home by mail with liner-notes. 

$257 Our Love's As Big As An Ocean - A digital pre-sale album and an option of a hard-copy album with signed liner notes, plus a bonus video of me singing a song I wrote just for you that you can share with everyone you know. 

$500 I'll Sing For You - Nothing says thank you more than a live concert with me singing favorites and covers from Home. Additional travel expenses may apply. Includes a digital copy of album and one autographed hard copy with autographed liner notes.


The Impact
 What fans often say is that whenever they hear my music, they feel happy. My music and performance helps their heart open, helps them touch feelings, love, warmth, memories that they have not been in touch with for a long time and did not know they have missed. Although I love being a musician and an artist, I believe my main work is as a listener. I listen to the stories that people share with me. I listen to prayers, dreams, hopes, desires of those in my life, and that's what I end up writing about. My songs are like prayers. They are ways to rekindle and to remember what matters most. And I believe that music-making is an art-form that transcends culture and yet speaks in culturally specific ways. But rhythm and song is a part of the earth, is part of every living being. 

I have been doing it myself and raising money for albums and performances for nearly twenty-five years. Fans have contributed to my music projects and travels by buying my music online and at shows, coming out to hear me play locally, booking house concerts and benefit performances, and some who have left me money in their wills and trusts.
 Honestly, I have not ever done music alone, because fans have been with me every step of the way. Every time I have written a song, it has been my fans in the front, middle, and back rows who have time and time again been there to experience the music first hand. I have a folder of letters I have received and an inbox full of messages from participant-audiences who have gifted me with their responses to my work, and the stories that brought them to my music, and what they remembered when they experienced it.    Risks & Challenges For me, the scariest challenge is not having faith enough in myself to continue this project to the end. Money means a lot, because it gets people in the space with me, turns on the power in the studio, and helps sign me up for distribution that will help get the music and my message out into the world, to people who may need it. I think of the many young artists out there who like me started out with people saying they couldn't do what they wanted to do with their music, or their art, or that they had to sacrifice some part of themselves in order to get noticed. That way doesn't cut it for me anymore, and I have endeavored with, Home, and my year-long artlovelegacies project to do music that feels like home. I continue finding myself through performance, lyrics, rhythm, and melody. And I continue to challenge myself even when a voice in the back of my head might say: "You can't do that." I hear you, voice, now watch me! 
I have been in the business of music-making long enough to know that being authentic makes the best kind of art, the art that feels good when it is delivered. It has taken a whole lot of space, healing, time, and loving community for me to find a voice that feels like home. I will never forget the legacies of which I am a part. The many patrons of my art. To you, a multitude of gratitude.   Other Ways You Can Help The best way you can be of help is to breathe and smile while visiting this campaign page. And if you like it and want to be of help but cannot contribute financially, please do share this page with friends. Please ask them to give because it is important to you, to me, and I believe to spreading love out into this world. Let your friends, family, and co-workers know how you were impacted by reading my story or watching my video.

story:
Small Kitchen Chaos Relocation Fund

Hello! We are Small Kitchen Chaos, a folk(ish) duo currently getting ready to leave Vernon, BC. We are made up of Trista Bassett and John Fraser. We are also two people who are seriously in love.  We met through music, and formed our duo a year ago.  In addition to performing live, we recorded our debut album, Never Have a Doubt, in early August, live at Hunter Audio in Kelowna, BC.  

A couple of months ago, John found out that his mother has fallen quite ill.  He hasn't been home to Nova Scotia for several years, so we have decided to get rid of almost everything we own, pack up the instruments, camping gear and Sid the Cat, and head out on the road towards Halifax.  

We are shorter on funds than we were expecting, thanks to some necessary and very costly van repairs, so we are trying to raise additional funds for our trip through the sale of our album, a fairwell concert, and this campaign.   

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are hoping to raise a minimum of $1000 to offset some of the van repair costs.  This money will go directly towards our gas for the trip, food, camping costs and potentially (but hopefully not) additional van repairs if that situation were to arise. 

We have a number of perks in mind, including a hand-written postcard from our journey, a personalized video of a song we have put your name in, Small Kitchen Chaos buttons, a signed (and hand-painted) copy of our album, and so much more!!

If we don't reach our goal, the funds we do collect will still go towards gas and travel expenses, but we really hope to reach our goal. 

The Impact

 

We perform heartfelt songs the show our passion for traveling, the outdoors, and our love for each other.  We are so grateful to have found each other and to have so much in common, including this music we are now creating as a duo.  We are also fun! (Although I, Trista, tend to be more of the "straight man" to John's funny).  We have had such positive feedback about our performance and music together and we look forward to being able to share our personalities and music with you, our supporters! 

 

Risks & Challenges

Well... We are heading across a very large country in our mini camper van.  Truth be told, any number of things could happen when traveling almost 6000km.   We are very lucky to have each other (and Sid the Cat).  We actually want to spend every minute together, so if we do get stranded in the middle of the country, we will still have each other, so that's basically all we need.  

That being said, we do hope we actually reach the other side in one piece, and hopefully with some funds to rent an apartment so we aren't camping in our tiny van in the early East Coast winter.  

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't financially able to support us at this time, you can still help us out by spreading the word about our campaign! Post the link on Facebook, tell people about what awesome humans we are (and Sid the Cat), tell them about the wonderful, fun and fantastic perks they will get by supporting us, and also, most importantly, that we are making this trip because we want to be closer to John's mother.  Your support, whether financial or word-of-mouth, is much appreciated.

story:
You may be asking yourself, “What is a ‘tasting concert?’"

Did you know that the descriptions used by wine experts to describe wine parallel the terms that musicians use to describe the elements of a classical voice?

...clear, bright, round, smoky, opulent, bold, medium-bodied...

Matthew Burns, an internationally-acclaimed bass-baritone with a passion for wine, created MAGNVM OPVS tasting concerts to explore how perfectly the language of wine appreciation is set up to help audiences gain a deeper understanding of the classical voice - and vice versa!

At a MAGNVM OPVS tasting concert, audiences are guided through a traditional wine tasting process, an exploration which uses the senses of sight, smell, taste, and touch. Only one is missing: hearing. Matthew solves this by building the wine tastings around specific singers, presenting specially curated wines alongside musical selections specifically chosen to highlight the parallels in the voice and the wine.

Most people boil down their opinions of these art forms to one adjective - “sweet”, "sharp", “strident” - or, even more simply, to a black-and-white statement: “I don’t like it” or “I love it!” After an evening with our singers and experts, we hope our guests will have a more informed palate and the ability to discern and express what they hear and taste.

Our intimate salon-like programs promise to change the way our guests think about wine and song!


But first, we need to get off the ground.

We are producing several events this fall in which we will put this concept into practice for the first time. 

Programs in New York, Boston, and Pittsburgh will feature such singers as Anne-Carolyn Bird, David Kravitz, Marco Nistico, Daniel Teadt, and Caroline Worra. Master sommelier David Keck, along with sommeliers and wine professionals, will work with Matthew to select wines for the events. AJV Media, a team of brothers with experience creating promotional videos for unique events, will capture the experience as our intimate audiences of wine experts, opera lovers, and advisors experience MAGNVM OPVS tasting concerts for the first time.


How can you help?

Here's what we need right now:

Start-up costs
$500    Video editing by AJV Media (You can see the final product at the top of the page!)
$200    Website: domain and hosting
$1400  Licensing and legal fees: Boring, but crucial.

Event costs
$500     Wine: Lots and lots of wine.
$500     Travel: ORF-->NYC-->BOS-->PIT
$140      Rentals: We need a LOT of wine glasses!
$200     Food: All wine and no nibbles makes... well, you know.
$500     Programs & marketing: Each guest receives a “tasting journal” unique to the event.
$500     Honorariums: Many of our artists are donating their talents for these first concerts - and we are so grateful!


Can't contribute financially at this time?

No problem! There are many ways you can help us get Magnvm Opvs tasting concerts off the ground. 

* Find and follow us on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter. Every time you share our postings, we attract new followers.

* Spread the word about Magnvm Opvs tasting concerts. Do you know someone who loves wine and knows a little about music? Or who loves opera but is intimidated by wine? They need a tasting concert! 

* And, of course, spread the word about our Indiegogo campaign!


Cheers, toi toi toi - and THANK YOU!!

story:
Art Haus 2018 Season

Last year we brought you Stravinsky's Rite of Spring beneath the Tree of Ténéré, the first ballet performance of its kind at Burning Man with a full orchestra amplified by Robot Heart. An audience of an estimated 10,000 Burners came out to witness the magic, proving a thirst for classical and ballet performances at Burning Man, and the experience was absolutely unforgettable.

Photo by Pascal Pincosy

video by Vincent Rommelaere 

This year, we knew we had to come back with more mind-blowing performances, and in order to be able to perform when and where we pleased without relying too much on other groups, we knew we needed an art car! Our wish came true in February when we were presented with the opportunity to adopt a 1981 Hahn Pumper Fire Truck! We intend to build the fire truck into a mobile stage, complete with recognizable sails in the image of the Sydney Opera House! 

We're turning this......

Into this!

Our 2018 Season

Inspired by all the incredible art pieces brought to Burning Man we will be presenting a symphonic performance of Mussorgsky's Pictures at an Exhibition in collaboration with The Baba Yaga House, the giant Step Forward puppets and Robot Heart as well as various other artists, to showcase and celebrate art in a much bigger way than Mussorgsky could have ever imagined. 

Reflecting this year's I, Robot theme, we will present We, Human, a new ballet work by Robert Dekkers set to Steve Reich's 8 Lines. 

Finally, at sunrise on Friday morning we will practice radical inclusion by inviting anyone with an instrument to join us in a performance of Terry Riley's masterpiece In C, which is written for any instrumentation and uses repeating figures and indeterminacy to create a massive, irreplicable musical experience. 

 

What We Need and What You Get

All of our performers are gifting their time and talents to these projects, and we have a dedicated team of art car builders who are donating their time and hard work, but we still have a lot of expenses involved in bringing both the performances and the art car to the playa. 

For our performances, we need to pay for rehearsal space, costumes, make up, marley, and various other equipment needs. We are fortunate to already have a lot of great equipment from our performance last year, so the vast majority of our funds will be going toward the art car, which will need a number of repairs in order to make it drivable, and will need funding in order to purchase the materials to build the stage and sails, as well as lighting and sound monitors. 

If we do not make it to our fundraising goal, we will still repair the fire truck to use for equipment transportation, but we won’t be able to fully transform it yet. This may become a 2 year build process. If we exceed our goal, we will be able to make the fire truck even more spectacular, and hopefully have money for extra costs that come up along the way. 

We are happy to offer a number of perks at varying donation levels! Please be sure to click the "Get this perk" button on the right hand side of this page under the perk you wish to claim. In addition to some awesome Art Haus Swag, we are offering several exciting Art Haus experiences.

  • For donations of $300 you are invited to join us on the evening of May 17 at the whimsical fantastical Gregangelo Museum (as seen in an upcoming Netflix special!) in the St Francis Wood neighborhood of SF for a special Pictures at an Exhibition- themed tour and cocktail party complete with Art Haus musician performances and a tasting menu! Each room is a whimsical storyboard for Gregangelo's Velocity Circus complete with installations, mosaics and a spiritual story. Click “get this perk” on the right to claim this perk!
  • For donations of $500 you are invited to come see our final dress rehearsal of Robert Dekkers new work We, Human on August 21 in San Francisco. This will be the only opportunity to see the work live if you are not going to Burning Man. Click “get this perk” on the right to claim this perk!
  • Have a friendly (or not-so-friendly) rivalry with another Burning Man Camp? For donations of $1,000 our professional brass section will go to the camp of your choosing on playa at an ungodly early hour, and play Reveille at the top of their lungs. Click “get this perk” on the right to claim this perk!
  • For donations of $2,000 we will send you a very special Mystery Prize. Click “get this perk” on the right to claim this perk!
  • For donations of $5,000 a small ensemble will come to your Burning Man camp, event, or special location and perform for half an hour, repertoire of your choosing (Perfect for special dinners, engagements or weddings!) Click “get this perk” on the right to claim this perk!

The Impact

We are proud to be pioneers in the realm of putting the spectacle back into classical & contemporary music and dance. With an incredibly successful Rite of Spring performance under our belt, we feel we've tapped into an exciting new style combining various artistic mediums. We believe that the work we create at Burning Man can also be brought home, which is why we're extremely excited to be building our mobile-stage art car. Once we create our mobile stage we plan to use it in the default world and well as on playa, so we can bring Art Haus pop-up performances to San Francisco and beyond! We feel there is no better way to promote classical music & dance than to be able to physically bring our performances anywhere we want! We're thinking ballets at Golden Gate Park, symphonies at Dolores park, string quartets at Ocean Beach, and beyond! We are ready to obliterate the idea that classical performances are only for a certain age or class of audience, or that performances need to take place in a stuff concert hall. Are you with us?

Risks & Challenges

Our goals are ambitious and we know we face many challenges but our determination is making it happen, and every bit of help we are given goes a long way.

With limited rehearsal time together before we hit the playa, every note counts, so our dancers and musicians are dedicating their time at the end of August to putting together the entire production in a matter of days. We need to be able to rent rehearsal space for them to do their work!

As we did last year, we are facing an arid desert environment where dust storms and intense winds are common. Are we crazy? Hell yes. Our fearless musicians are dedicated to playing regardless of the weather, our dancers will dance through dust-storms. With the open playa as our theater our sound could easily get lost, so as we did last year we will be miking our orchestra and plugging into the Robot Heart sound bus for amplification. In order to do so, we need to add more sound equipment to accommodate a larger orchestra.

One reason classical music has been so underrepresented at Burning Man is that musicians are reluctant to bring their instruments to the dusty, windy desert environment. We are working to find appropriate used instruments for all our performers. If you are able to donate a used instrument, it will be much appreciated! 

Last year we depended heavily on passing art cars to help us transport our large instruments (basses, timpani, percussion equipment) chairs and sound equipment, and were even left in the dust after the performance with our three large timpani and no way to get them home! Our musicians had to transport their own instruments and stands, but their determination made it happen. This year we will be able to transport our own equipment, on our own art car, and set up our own stage so our orchestra can focus on their job- playing amazing music really well! We are racing the clock to get our art car prepared in time for Burning Man but our dedicated team has already planned out work weekends to get it done! Every dollar helps us get there! 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Are you a performer, who is interested in joining us? We are looking for dancers of all experience levels, backgrounds, and ages to join us for We, Human. Dancers must be able to attend rehearsals in San Francisco at the end of August. To sign up, please fill out this form.
  • We are also looking for professional and semi-professional musicians who can join us for rehearsals in San Francisco to play in Pictures at an Exhibition and 8 Lines, and any musicians who wish to join us on playa for In C. To sign up, please fill out this form.
  • Do you want to help build an art car? No experience required! We are building the car in Santa Rosa and need many hands (and brains) to make it happen! Please email info@arthausonplaya.com to get involved! 
  • Do you have an old instrument you don't play anymore and wish to donate? Many of our musicians cannot bring their own expensive instruments, so donations of used instruments are greatly appreciated!  Please email us at info@arthausonplaya.com
  • Art Haus is also creating a camp this year to help house our performers, and are looking for experienced campers or camp leads who are willing to help with planning and logistics, set-up and tear-down and generally keeping camp running smoothly! If this is your forte and you want to join us, please email us at info@arthausonplaya.com

For donations of $300 you are invited to join us on the evening of May 17 at the whimsical fantastical Gregangelo Museum (as seen in an upcoming Netflix special!) in the St Francis Wood neighborhood of SF for a special Pictures at an Exhibition- themed tour and cocktail party complete with Art Haus musician performances and a tasting menu! Each room is a whimsical storyboard for Gregangelo's Velocity Circus complete with installations, mosaics and a spiritual story. Click “get this perk” on the right to claim this perk!
For donations of $500 you are invited to come see our final dress rehearsal of Robert Dekkers new work We, Human on August 21 in San Francisco. This will be the only opportunity to see the work live if you are not going to Burning Man. Click “get this perk” on the right to claim this perk!
Have a friendly (or not-so-friendly) rivalry with another Burning Man Camp? For donations of $1,000 our professional brass section will go to the camp of your choosing on playa at an ungodly early hour, and play Reveille at the top of their lungs. Click “get this perk” on the right to claim this perk!
For donations of $2,000 we will send you a very special Mystery Prize. Click “get this perk” on the right to claim this perk!
For donations of $5,000 a small ensemble will come to your Burning Man camp, event, or special location and perform for half an hour, repertoire of your choosing (Perfect for special dinners, engagements or weddings!) Click “get this perk” on the right to claim this perk!


The Impact
We are proud to be pioneers in the realm of putting the spectacle back into classical & contemporary music and dance. With an incredibly successful Rite of Spring performance under our belt, we feel we've tapped into an exciting new style combining various artistic mediums. We believe that the work we create at Burning Man can also be brought home, which is why we're extremely excited to be building our mobile-stage art car. Once we create our mobile stage we plan to use it in the default world and well as on playa, so we can bring Art Haus pop-up performances to San Francisco and beyond! We feel there is no better way to promote classical music & dance than to be able to physically bring our performances anywhere we want! We're thinking ballets at Golden Gate Park, symphonies at Dolores park, string quartets at Ocean Beach, and beyond! We are ready to obliterate the idea that classical performances are only for a certain age or class of audience, or that performances need to take place in a stuff concert hall. Are you with us?

Risks & Challenges
Our goals are ambitious and we know we face many challenges but our determination is making it happen, and every bit of help we are given goes a long way.
With limited rehearsal time together before we hit the playa, every note counts, so our dancers and musicians are dedicating their time at the end of August to putting together the entire production in a matter of days. We need to be able to rent rehearsal space for them to do their work!
As we did last year, we are facing an arid desert environment where dust storms and intense winds are common. Are we crazy? Hell yes. Our fearless musicians are dedicated to playing regardless of the weather, our dancers will dance through dust-storms. With the open playa as our theater our sound could easily get lost, so as we did last year we will be miking our orchestra and plugging into the Robot Heart sound bus for amplification. In order to do so, we need to add more sound equipment to accommodate a larger orchestra.
One reason classical music has been so underrepresented at Burning Man is that musicians are reluctant to bring their instruments to the dusty, windy desert environment. We are working to find appropriate used instruments for all our performers. If you are able to donate a used instrument, it will be much appreciated! 
Last year we depended heavily on passing art cars to help us transport our large instruments (basses, timpani, percussion equipment) chairs and sound equipment, and were even left in the dust after the performance with our three large timpani and no way to get them home! Our musicians had to transport their own instruments and stands, but their determination made it happen. This year we will be able to transport our own equipment, on our own art car, and set up our own stage so our orchestra can focus on their job- playing amazing music really well! We are racing the clock to get our art car prepared in time for Burning Man but our dedicated team has already planned out work weekends to get it done! Every dollar helps us get there! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Are you a performer, who is interested in joining us? We are looking for dancers of all experience levels, backgrounds, and ages to join us for We, Human. Dancers must be able to attend rehearsals in San Francisco at the end of August. To sign up, please fill out this form.
We are also looking for professional and semi-professional musicians who can join us for rehearsals in San Francisco to play in Pictures at an Exhibition and 8 Lines, and any musicians who wish to join us on playa for In C. To sign up, please fill out this form.
Do you want to help build an art car? No experience required! We are building the car in Santa Rosa and need many hands (and brains) to make it happen! Please email info@arthausonplaya.com to get involved! 
Do you have an old instrument you don't play anymore and wish to donate? Many of our musicians cannot bring their own expensive instruments, so donations of used instruments are greatly appreciated!  Please email us at info@arthausonplaya.com
Art Haus is also creating a camp this year to help house our performers, and are looking for experienced campers or camp leads who are willing to help with planning and logistics, set-up and tear-down and generally keeping camp running smoothly! If this is your forte and you want to join us, please email us at info@arthausonplaya.com

story:
NEW Lawlor Music Single: Tomorrow

Introducing the new Single from Dale Winters and Chris Adams!
 


 

 

The Music

This single has been in the works for almost six months!

This will be the debut single for artist Dale Winters.

It's a little different from many of Chris Adams previous releases.

This is a single we are very proud to present to you. 

 

Artwork

The artwork for Tomorrow was inspired by the idea and saying that "Tomorrow is another day"  using the dandelion seed to make a wish.

 

We also wanted to make the visual imagery more about the music, and the song itself although a very tragic topic is full of hope, faith and is all about the fight.

 

 

Thanks to the talent of Joe McGrath of Hellfire Studios and all the musicians involved, we were able to make this idea, this vision, possible. I hope you like it. :)

 

 

The Cause

A new day ward for Haematology day ward for patients in Tallaght Hospital

The new ward provides a dedicated space specifically for Haematology patients, with both benign and malignant haematological disorders, including ambulatory care, blood testing and specific treatments such as chemotherapy and blood transfusions. The Ward also offers a walk-in service for patients with active haematological diagnoses who become unwell unexpectedly as well as a rapid access clinic for patients with acute haematological problems led by Consultants.

The Irish Cancer Society

The inspiration

 

Jennifer's nephew Luke getting leukemia at 17 and still battling through it now at 20 such a wonderful positive child never once complained always thinking of others before himself.

Such a beautiful soul the doctors nurses his team all the staff from the tea lady to the night porter are awesome the treatment he continues to receive from tallaght hospital is second to none all positive and helpful.

Let the sun shine on Each and every one of them Irish cancer society to help continue with cancer research so that one day no Other family will have to go through any heartbreak of the big C.

History

This single began almost a year ago with the song being penned by Jennifer Lawlor because of her personal experience 

 

A rough demo version was recorded on an iphone just an acoustic guitar and vocal..

 

The song developed then in the studio with the work of Dale Winters, Chris Adams, Joe McGrath and Naill Lawlor.

The recording took shape and became the cross between Dire Straits and Fleetwood Mac that we can listen and love now!

 

I hope you'll love this single as much as we have loved creating it.

 

 

Musicians On This Album

 

Dale Winters - Vocals Location: Ireland

Dale based in Dublin is a really talented singer/father and all round lovelly guy.. 

 

Chris Adams - Drums/Bass/guitars
Location: Scotland

It was an absolute thrill and pleasure to feature Chris on this single. The drums,bass & guitars he added are absolutely perfect and added some incredible magic to the song. 

 

 

Naill Lawlor  - Lap Steel
Location: Ireland

Naill is a busker on the streets of Dublin, many a tourist has filmed Naill

you wont have to look far on youtube to find viral video's of Nall doing his thing. He gave up his days busking earnings to give his time and talent.

 

 

 

 

OTHER CONTRIBUTORS

 

Jennifer Lawlor - Song Writer/Producer

Location: Ireland

Jennifer put her heart and soul into the song along with motivating the other contributors and seeing the vision through to completion.

Jennifer is a force to be reckoned with.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Joe McGrath - Recording Engineer

Location: Ireland

 

 Joe this a gifted recording engineer which involve a lot more than being an expert audio technician. Joe has a natural way with people and can make them comfortable getting the best out of them in a totally no intimidating way.

Joe has put in many hours of work on the making of the single.

 

Looking back over the past couple years, it's really amazing how this has all come together. I've learned over the years that nothing of worth is ever easy.  This single is no different. 

 

 

I would be absolutely honored if you decide to be a Co-Quester & help with the final completion of this single and its release very soon!

 

 

==========================>

 

HOW YOU CAN BE INVOLVED:

 

⚔️⚔️ Super hero Bundle ⚔️⚔️

 

This bundle is reserved for the elite super hero's out there.

This bundle includes:

  • The autographed Digipack cd
  • The digital  download
  • The high quality wav master digital download
  • The digital special Chris Adams version of the single
  • Exclusive t-shirt!
  • digital wallpapers of original artwork
  • Your name in a future Tomorrow lyric video credits!

Limited to 250 orders!

 

⚔️ Hero one Bundle ⚔️

 

Prove yourself worthy and claim the Hero one's Bundle!

This bundle includes:

  • The autographed Digipack cd
  • The digital download
  • The digital special chris Adams version of the single
  •  digital wallpapers of original artwork

 

 

⚔️ Hero two Bundle ⚔️

 

Prove yourself worthy and claim the Hero two's Bundle!

This bundle includes:

  • The digital download
  • The digital special chris Adams version of the single
  •  digital wallpapers of original artwork

⚔️ Hero  Bundle ⚔️

 

Prove yourself worthy and claim the Hero  Bundle!

This bundle includes:

  • The digital download
  •  digital wallpapers of original artwork

 

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN BE INVOLVED:
 

  • SHARE this campaign every few days with your network - Look for the Share buttons at the top of this campaign
  • EMBED this campaign on your website or blog
  • Spread the word to your friends & colleagues who might enjoy new the song and various versions.
  • If you're a music reviewer or promoter, we have spaces for interviews! Please send a message to marketing@lawlormusic.com with the subject line: "Interview" 

 

 

I look forward to you joining The Quest with me, 

Chris Adams

story:
You may know him from his work with Southampton freak-boppers The Mojo Co. You may know him such centuries as the 19th and his mad work on Bavarian castles. However you know him, new or familiar to you, this madman is bringing his first record to the world, and would love you to be a part of it.

Described by BBC 6 Music's Tom Robinson as having a "foghorn voice [that] is joyfully at odds with his androgynous image", Mad King Ludwig is an unmistakeable character with a mad story. His positive energy for a more colourful, mad and tolerant world is channelled into 9 eclectic songs which consider every side of that famous but often ignored phrase, 'Do What Makes You Happy'.

Recorded August-October 2018, partly on a houseboat in Southampton, UK, with producer Jake Wilmott, 'Do What Makes You Happy' showcases Mad King Ludwig's novel-esque songwriting ability and octopus-like musical talent - he sings, plays guitar, piano, saxophone, double bass and kitchen percussion on the album. A full band and special guests feature along the way, and pigeon-holing the album's style is both pointless and insensitive to pigeons.

Rewards for helping to support this album include a signed copy of the album and a ticket to the release show, at the Joiners, Southampton on Sat 26th January 2019 - both for a tenner, cheaper than both bought separately! Ludwig is collaborating with acclaimed photographer Brandon Otto to create a limited edition photo book cataloguing the choicest, maddest moments with the Mojo Co. and solo over the past few years.vHe is also working with artist Candy Joyce to offer you a unique piece of artwork that will be created in line with your own interpretation of the album!

Brandon Otto, Photographer - http://bottophoto.com/
Candy Joyce, Artist - https://www.candyjoyce.co.uk/

Mad King Ludwig is enormously proud of this record, and believes it is a worthy tonic to these turbulent times, indeed any time.

Be his special guest, and be a part of bringing 'Do What Makes You Happy' out into the world.

story:
This is PART 2 of our ongoing campaign to fund the production of an album of world premieres by Costa Rican composers who live abroad. We raised a total of $1530, with which we will pay for the recording (video and audio), but we need a little bit more to afford mixing and mastering the tracks, designing and editing the CD's artwork, printing the actual CDs, tickets to Costa Rica to supervise rehearsals, and other post-production expenses.

We are 4 emerging Costa Rican composers based abroad who were chosen to write new original works for an upcoming July concert by the Orquesta Sinfónica de Heredia. Since it is rare in Costa Rica to have a concert showcasing the music of young composers, we want to take this opportunity to professionally film and record it – our goal is to encourage the current establishment of concert music in Costa Rica to entrust a new generation of composers with more opportunities to have our music performed.

We need your financial support  to cover expenses for video/audio recording, traveling to Costa Rica for the rehearsals, mixing & mastering, album art design, and CD production, among other things. Usually these expenses are covered by state funds (the private sector's help in art is almost non-existent in Costa Rica), but shrinking budgets in times of economic austerity have made it difficult to find the financial assistance we need.

We agreed to write these works for free because we believe in the value that creating new art has in the shaping of culture. We are simply hoping to cover the expenses associated with producing a top-notch audiovisual recording and making it available for online streaming, as well as having a hard copy that we can share with our contacts. Scroll down to get to know who we are!

Event Details

Mostly comprised by young musicians, the Orquesta Sinfónica de Heredia is an orchestra that focuses on new and unexplored music from Latin America. Under the leadership of Latin Grammy winner composer and conductor Eddie Mora, it has risen to a prominent role in Costa Rican culture, performing works by Latin American composers and recording several albums during the last few years. For its fourth concert of the 2018 season, Eddie decided to yield the baton to a young Costa Rican conductor based in South Dakota, Luis A. Viquez, and let him premiere 4 new works by 4 emerging composers who live outside of Costa Rica: Pablo Chin (who lives in NYC), Jose Mora Jimenez (who lives in the Netherlands), Guido Sanchez (who lives in Illinois, USA) and Andrés Soto (who lives in New Jersey, USA)

Two concerts are scheduled:

July 21st, Parroquia Inmaculada Concepción, Heredia, Costa Rica. (8pm)

July 22nd, Eugene O'Neill Theater, San José, Costa Rica. (11am)

Carlos "Pipo" Chaves, a Latin Grammy-winning sound engineer, has offered to record the concert for us for a reduced fee, so we are hoping to produce a first-rate audiovisual recording that shows a new generation of Costa Rican musicians coming into their own with the help of two established figures.

What We Need 

We already raised $1530 in our first campaign! We are going to use those funds to pay for the live recording (both video and audio). Now we need a little bit more for the following expenses:

$500 for additional mixing/mastering.

$600 for CD-production expenses (printing, editing, streaming fees, etc)

$400 for album cover artwork design*

Total: $1500

Optional: if we raise extra money, we will use an additional $1500 for traveling expenses to Costa Rica for 2 composers, 2 weeks (Soto and Chin)

IndieGogo charges 5% of our crowdfunding total 

*We want to commission a young Costa Rican artist (TBA) to design the cover art for our album. 

If we don't reach the goal, whatever we get will go towards recording and traveling expenses. Keep in mind IndieGogo charges 5% of our crowdfunding campaign!

Check the perks we offer!

The Impact

With your generous donation, you would be supporting the development of Costa Rica's next generation of composers and contributing towards having a stronger presence in the Latin American concert music scene. We plan to share this album around the world so we can inspire younger composers to continue to strive in their quest for obtaining commissions, while also hoping to encourage other institutions (both in the U.S., Europe, and Latin America) to support Hispanic composers by commissioning their music more often. Last year, the National Symphony of Costa Rica actually won a Latin Grammy for the first time with an album of works by Costa Rican composers from previous generations (which was, incidentally, produced by Eddie Mora and Carlos "Pipo" Chaves). With their help, we plan to submit this CD to try to compete in the same category next year.

We thank you for your generous donation, and please remember to share this campaign on your social media platforms!

 

Meet the Composers

 

Pablo Santiago Chin


Having just relocated from Chicago to New York, Pablo Chin is an adjunct professor of electronic music at Drew University. Recent works by Chin draw inspiration from the narratives of film and literature, phonetic structures in text, and the use of idiosyncratic transcription methods that enable imaginative exploration of pre-existent musical sources.
His music has been performed in South, Central and North America; in Israel, Asia and in Europe. Chin is co-founder and artistic director of the Fonema Consort, a Chicago-based ensemble dedicated to commissioning and fostering works that explore the capabilities of the human voice in the context of late 20th and 21st centuries.
Website: http://www.pablochin.com/


Jose Mora-Jimenez

Jose Mora-Jimenez resides in the Netherlands since 2006 and completed his composition studies at the Royal Conservatory in The Hague under Gilius van Bergeijk and Cornelis de Bondt. He has received several awards, including the International Timo Korhonen Composition Competition, the 4th Calefax Reed Quintet Competition, 50th anniversary award of the "Vrienden van het Lied" association. A multitalented man, he also is an active composer for video games and has a Masters degree in Cultural Economics and Entrepeneurship from the Erasmus University in Rotterdam. His music is performed in different countries around the world and is published by Berben Edizioni Musicali in Italy and Les Productions D’OZ in Canada.
Website: http://www.josemorajimenez.com/

 

Guido Sanchez Portuguez

An active performer, educator and composer based in Illinois, Guido is one of the most talented guitarists to come out of Costa Rica, having obtained a full scholarship to study guitar at the University of Indiana, where he completed his doctorate in 2012. He has recorded 5 albums with Costa Rican guitar orchestras, and has produced and arranged albums for Grammy winner Sylvia McNair and the Latin American Popular Music Ensemble of the Jacobs School of Music. 
He is currently professor of classical guitar at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.

Website: https://www.guidoguitar.com/

 

Andrés Soto Marín

Based in New York City, Andrés Soto is an active composer of both film music and concert music. He obtained a scholarship from the National Hispanic Foundation for the Arts to study at New York University, where he obtained a masters degree in 2011. Recently, his Suite No.1 from "La Rosa y el Niño", was premiered at the Palau de les Arts Reina Sofia in Valencia, Spain, where it was well received. The National Symphony of Costa Rica has commissioned him with large-scale works in two occasions, in 2015 and 2016. Incidentally, the Orquesta Sinfónica de Heredia was the first ensemble to ever commission a piece from him, in 2012. Recent film scores include "Buscando a Marcos Ramirez" and "He Matado a mi Marido", as well as the video game "Guns of Icarus: Alliance." His music is published by Abundant Silence.

Website: www.andres-soto.net / www.facebook.com/andres.soto.composer

 

Meet the Conductor

Luis A. Viquez

Luis A. Viquez is a Costa Rican native who enjoys an international career both as a clarinetist and as an orchestral, opera and wind band conductor. As Director of Orchestral Activities at the University of South Dakota (USA) Víquez is the Music Director of the University of South Dakota Symphony Orchestra. Víquez has performed and conducted throughout the United States, Costa Rica, Panama, Colombia, Guatemala, Honduras, England and Taiwan. As a guest conductor, Víquez has led the orchestras of the University of Missouri, the Cartago Symphony Orchestra, the Midwest Chamber Ensemble of Kansas City, the Truman Symphony Orchestra, the Truman State University Wind Symphony and Concert Band, and the National Symphonic Band of San Jose. He has been a featured conductor at the 2013 Music Teachers National Association Conference in Anaheim, California, and recently performed as a guest soloist at the 2016 Missouri Music Educators Conference and  at the 2016 NACUSA National Composers USA Conference in Knoxville, TN. Opera conducting appearances include Menotti's "The Old Maid and the Thief" with the Truman Opera Theater in 2013, Mozart's "Die Zauberflote" and Britten's "The Turn of the Screw" with the UMKC Opera Theater in 2015 and 2016; and "Die Fledermaus" wiith the University of South Dakota Opera in 2017. 


Guest Soloist - Marcela Alfaro, mezzo soprano

Marcela Alfaro is a Costa Rican mezzo soprano with an active international career, having performed in festivals and recitals in Mexico, Spain, Colombia, Cuba, and Central America. She’s the lead mezzo soprano of Syntagma Musicum, a chamber ensemble that won the National Music Award in 2013. In 2007 she won the Young Soloists Competition in Costa Rica. Recent performances include featured soloist in Handel’s Messiah at the Teatro Ruben Dario in Nicaragua, and in Beethoven’s 9th at the National Theater of Costa Rica. She is also an active educator at the University of Costa Rica (her alma mater) and the Innova Music School.

We are simply hoping to cover the expenses associated with producing a top-notch audiovisual recording and making it available for online streaming, as well as having a hard copy that we can share with our contacts. Scroll down to get to know who we are!
Event Details
Mostly comprised by young musicians, the Orquesta Sinfónica de Heredia is an orchestra that focuses on new and unexplored music from Latin America. Under the leadership of Latin Grammy winner composer and conductor Eddie Mora, it has risen to a prominent role in Costa Rican culture, performing works by Latin American composers and recording several albums during the last few years. For its fourth concert of the 2018 season, Eddie decided to yield the baton to a young Costa Rican conductor based in South Dakota, Luis A. Viquez, and let him premiere 4 new works by 4 emerging composers who live outside of Costa Rica: Pablo Chin (who lives in NYC), Jose Mora Jimenez (who lives in the Netherlands), Guido Sanchez (who lives in Illinois, USA) and Andrés Soto (who lives in New Jersey, USA)
Two concerts are scheduled:
July 21st, Parroquia Inmaculada Concepción, Heredia, Costa Rica. (8pm)
July 22nd, Eugene O'Neill Theater, San José, Costa Rica. (11am)
Carlos "Pipo" Chaves, a Latin Grammy-winning sound engineer, has offered to record the concert for us for a reduced fee, so we are hoping to produce a first-rate audiovisual recording that shows a new generation of Costa Rican musicians coming into their own with the help of two established figures.

What We Need 
We already raised $1530 in our first campaign! We are going to use those funds to pay for the live recording (both video and audio). Now we need a little bit more for the following expenses:
$500 for additional mixing/mastering.
$600 for CD-production expenses (printing, editing, streaming fees, etc)
$400 for album cover artwork design*
Total: $1500
Optional: if we raise extra money, we will use an additional $1500 for traveling expenses to Costa Rica for 2 composers, 2 weeks (Soto and Chin)
IndieGogo charges 5% of our crowdfunding total 
*We want to commission a young Costa Rican artist (TBA) to design the cover art for our album. 
If we don't reach the goal, whatever we get will go towards recording and traveling expenses. Keep in mind IndieGogo charges 5% of our crowdfunding campaign!
Check the perks we offer!
The Impact
With your generous donation, you would be supporting the development of Costa Rica's next generation of composers and contributing towards having a stronger presence in the Latin American concert music scene. We plan to share this album around the world so we can inspire younger composers to continue to strive in their quest for obtaining commissions, while also hoping to encourage other institutions (both in the U.S., Europe, and Latin America) to support Hispanic composers by commissioning their music more often. Last year, the National Symphony of Costa Rica actually won a Latin Grammy for the first time with an album of works by Costa Rican composers from previous generations (which was, incidentally, produced by Eddie Mora and Carlos "Pipo" Chaves). With their help, we plan to submit this CD to try to compete in the same category next year.
We thank you for your generous donation, and please remember to share this campaign on your social media platforms!
 
Meet the Composers
 
Pablo Santiago Chin
Having just relocated from Chicago to New York, Pablo Chin is an adjunct professor of electronic music at Drew University. Recent works by Chin draw inspiration from the narratives of film and literature, phonetic structures in text, and the use of idiosyncratic transcription methods that enable imaginative exploration of pre-existent musical sources.His music has been performed in South, Central and North America; in Israel, Asia and in Europe. Chin is co-founder and artistic director of the Fonema Consort, a Chicago-based ensemble dedicated to commissioning and fostering works that explore the capabilities of the human voice in the context of late 20th and 21st centuries.Website: http://www.pablochin.com/
Jose Mora-Jimenez

Jose Mora-Jimenez resides in the Netherlands since 2006 and completed his composition studies at the Royal Conservatory in The Hague under Gilius van Bergeijk and Cornelis de Bondt. He has received several awards, including the International Timo Korhonen Composition Competition, the 4th Calefax Reed Quintet Competition, 50th anniversary award of the "Vrienden van het Lied" association. A multitalented man, he also is an active composer for video games and has a Masters degree in Cultural Economics and Entrepeneurship from the Erasmus University in Rotterdam. His music is performed in different countries around the world and is published by Berben Edizioni Musicali in Italy and Les Productions D’OZ in Canada.Website: http://www.josemorajimenez.com/
 
Guido Sanchez Portuguez

An active performer, educator and composer based in Illinois, Guido is one of the most talented guitarists to come out of Costa Rica, having obtained a full scholarship to study guitar at the University of Indiana, where he completed his doctorate in 2012. He has recorded 5 albums with Costa Rican guitar orchestras, and has produced and arranged albums for Grammy winner Sylvia McNair and the Latin American Popular Music Ensemble of the Jacobs School of Music. He is currently professor of classical guitar at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.
Website: https://www.guidoguitar.com/
 
Andrés Soto Marín
Based in New York City, Andrés Soto is an active composer of both film music and concert music. He obtained a scholarship from the National Hispanic Foundation for the Arts to study at New York University, where he obtained a masters degree in 2011. Recently, his Suite No.1 from "La Rosa y el Niño", was premiered at the Palau de les Arts Reina Sofia in Valencia, Spain, where it was well received. The National Symphony of Costa Rica has commissioned him with large-scale works in two occasions, in 2015 and 2016. Incidentally, the Orquesta Sinfónica de Heredia was the first ensemble to ever commission a piece from him, in 2012. Recent film scores include "Buscando a Marcos Ramirez" and "He Matado a mi Marido", as well as the video game "Guns of Icarus: Alliance." His music is published by Abundant Silence.
Website: www.andres-soto.net / www.facebook.com/andres.soto.composer
 
Meet the Conductor

Luis A. Viquez
Luis A. Viquez is a Costa Rican native who enjoys an international career both as a clarinetist and as an orchestral, opera and wind band conductor. As Director of Orchestral Activities at the University of South Dakota (USA) Víquez is the Music Director of the University of South Dakota Symphony Orchestra. Víquez has performed and conducted throughout the United States, Costa Rica, Panama, Colombia, Guatemala, Honduras, England and Taiwan. As a guest conductor, Víquez has led the orchestras of the University of Missouri, the Cartago Symphony Orchestra, the Midwest Chamber Ensemble of Kansas City, the Truman Symphony Orchestra, the Truman State University Wind Symphony and Concert Band, and the National Symphonic Band of San Jose. He has been a featured conductor at the 2013 Music Teachers National Association Conference in Anaheim, California, and recently performed as a guest soloist at the 2016 Missouri Music Educators Conference and  at the 2016 NACUSA National Composers USA Conference in Knoxville, TN. Opera conducting appearances include Menotti's "The Old Maid and the Thief" with the Truman Opera Theater in 2013, Mozart's "Die Zauberflote" and Britten's "The Turn of the Screw" with the UMKC Opera Theater in 2015 and 2016; and "Die Fledermaus" wiith the University of South Dakota Opera in 2017. 
Guest Soloist - Marcela Alfaro, mezzo soprano

Marcela Alfaro is a Costa Rican mezzo soprano with an active international career, having performed in festivals and recitals in Mexico, Spain, Colombia, Cuba, and Central America. She’s the lead mezzo soprano of Syntagma Musicum, a chamber ensemble that won the National Music Award in 2013. In 2007 she won the Young Soloists Competition in Costa Rica. Recent performances include featured soloist in Handel’s Messiah at the Teatro Ruben Dario in Nicaragua, and in Beethoven’s 9th at the National Theater of Costa Rica. She is also an active educator at the University of Costa Rica (her alma mater) and the Innova Music School.

story:
Drummer Ralph Peterson, and his Onyx Productions Music Label proudly presents:

The Gen-Next (Generation Next) Jazz Messenger Big Band with special guest saxophonist and Jazz Messenger alumni Donald Harrison, this ensemble of talented musicians,is  under the direction of the Berklee professor and widely acclaimed jazz master Ralph Peterson.

Ralph Peterson became a Jazz Messenger in March of 1983 at a concert that was part of the then Boston Globe Festival.  Ralph was chosen by Art Blakey, to perform with him in his two drummer Jazz Messenger Big Band. Peterson held the post until Mr. Blakey’s passing in 1990 and he has since led a consistently excellent bands and worked with hundreds of top musicians over a more than 30 year career that includes 20 recordings as a leader. 

A bandleader and educator and having played a significant role in launching the careers of Sean Jones, Tia Fuller, Justin Faulkner, and Orrin Evans, among others, Peterson lives the                    Jazz Messenger tradition of mentoring young musicians. These two threads of this multi faceted artist come together in this exciting project. This band was formed at Berklee College of Music where Professor Peterson teaches drumming and ensembles. The Big Band is made of up of the best and brightest students from Berklee and features the two drummer format in which Peterson musically directs and conducts the young musicians in the Blakey style.

We need your financial support to get this project released in October during the week of Art Blakey's 99th Birthday to kick off the celebration of his Centennial anniversary as one of the most important leaders in American Classical Music also known as Jazz.

story:
Mahya Veray y su trauma es un colectivo musical creado por Mahya Veray sobrina del conocido compositor y maestro de musica puertorriqueño Amaury Veray, creador del Villancico Yaucano.

 En este proyecto, Mahya de voz enigmática y seductora se une a diversos músicos internacionales  para hacer música al estilo "AfroCaribbean" / Fusión Caribeña/Afropop.

 El resultado es un cóctel que contiene desde delicadas melodías hasta un afro pop sofisticado y actual que invita a bailar.

Para Mahya, el golpe en el tambor, es la conexión con el alma.

Mahya través de sus melodías nos cuentan su irreverencia y sentido del humor en tiempos de trauma algo que hacia mucho Celia Cruz y La Lupe para la época de la Fania.Su raíz multicultural hace de su estilo uno sabroso para el deleite de sus seguidores.

Mahya posee un registro de voz único e impecable pero su manera de cantar conecta con el espíritu  sus dotes de tarima logran cautivarte y transpórtate a épocas,  donde la voz, sudar y el feeling eran primordiales.

Su concepto musical el Trauma son músicos especializados en el jazz y en este disco han tocado un batallón de artistas de la nueva escuela del afrocaribeña. Ellos, con su talento logran una sonoridad y versatilidad única.  Mahya Veray y su Trauma es ese ADN que nos caracteriza como antillanos esa mescolanza de sabores, ritmos, colores, que nos hace tan distintivos.

Mahya Veray representa una música del nuevo caribe, el de los que sueña con alas en los pies. Esto lo escribió un crítico de música en Cuba para una revista americana. 

Su raíz multicultural hacen de su estilo uno único y sabroso para el deleite de sus seguidores.

La Sade antillana con el vozarrón de la Adele pero en castellano le dicen en los suburbios de Santurce su ciudad natal en PR.

El golpe en el tambor es la conexión con las Antillas y sus raíces africanas,  eso es lo que veremos  como protagonista en este disco. Sabrosura Caribeña!. Contamos con 9 temas como Bagua, Pepita de Grosella, Ombligo a Destiempo, Lamento, Barrio, Energía Sutil, Tu me gustas mucho, La Nana del gato hasta su tan divertida canción Carmen, la Cachapera nos llevan a través de sus melodías, irreverentes con un  sentido del humor realista pero mágico. A sanar en tiempos de trauma. Todos los temas son autoría de Mahya Veray y en algunos temas colaboró con el cantautor cubano Xino Carrasco, el pianista puertorriqueño Eduardo Zayas y el  productor uruguayo Gonzalo López. 

Han colaborado músicos de la escuela de la bomba, de la plena, del rock funk, del flamenco, jazz, de salsa y de la rumba española creando un sonido bien mágico y único que sin duda Mahya Veray denomina Afroantillano.Sabrosura para los mulatos y cosa buena es el sentir de los Traumáticos.

Mahya Veray is a Puerto Rican artist, singer that marks in her tones and melodies the caribbean beat composed by the tropical magic that characterizes the island. María José Veray Mazo, also known in the warm streets of Puerto Rico as Mahya, is the daughter of multiculturalism being the child of a Puerto Rican father and a Spanish mother. Growing up between the amalgamate of cultures and being the niece of one of the best Puerto Rican composers, Amaury Veray (composer of “Villancico Yaucano”), generated in her soul a fervor passion for music since she was a little girl.

Also, as an infant, Mahya understood the importance and the role of music; it unites, shakes the spirit, and encourage even the shy and modest hearts to dance and animate their own existence.
The music of Mahya Veray is an AfroPopWorld that drifts to an interweave of music genres as reggae, bolero, pop, salsa, bomba, plena, rumba, afro beat, and jazz. Just imagine the days of La Fania with La Lupe and Celia Cruz mixing with Fela on stage. Emotions, spiritual vibes, warmth, and affections are many of the sensations that are transmitted through her strong and independent songs. One of the best Puerto Rican contemporary performer, Pedro Adorno, allege that “ Mahya has one of the best voices of Puerto Rico.” As a consequence, her voice and music has gained popularity in places as Santurce and Río Piedras where a contrasting public from young to adults unite acclaiming her music.

In the 2018 Mahya Veray and her team decided to take another step in her music career conspiring to produce a disc with seven songs originally written and composed by her. Moreover her music appeals to a colorful and variated public from different ages and ethnics, which also opens a window for concerts and music festivals around the world.

 Todo grabado en el estudio de Gozalo López donde graba Vico C, y Wisin.

La recaudación de fondos son para:

1-Terminar en el estudio la  grabación de voces, batería,  coros, dos temas y ciertos instrumentos.

2-Premezcla en el estudio de Gonzalo López.

3-Mescla real en Playback.

4-Masterización.

5-Registrar el disco y gestiones legales.

6-Caratula/ Fotos/Confección de arte/ etc.

7-Distribución y subidas Spotify, Itunes etc.

8-Publicidad del disco en redes sociales.

9-Copista

Llevo muchos años haciendo lo que me gusta,  Desde María con el sudor de mi frente y  sacrificio he logrado grabar los temas. Necesito  un empujoncito para traer a la vida el Trauma en plataformas de streaming, en tu carro, en tu casa, en fin donde nos queremos poner traumáticos y gozar. ¡Cuento contigo! Abrazo bien grande de parte de esta traumática. Cosa buena pa' ti.

Todo lo mejor!

Mahya Veray

story:
I am Adrian. I am an English musician living in Prague, Czech Republic. I produced 4 albums with my band The Prostitutes and two solo albums. My first solo album was awarded the Apollo Award 2014 for the Album of the Year in the Czech Republic. Below is a video for the song Blood on my hand's which  we made on the release of my second solo album Night and Day

 

 

And this is Sylvia, the creme-de-la-creme Grammy-award winning American music producer. Yes, that Sylvia who has worked with Johnny Cash, Prince, Tom Petty and The Heartbreakers, System of a Down, Red Hot Chilli Peppers and you name it. Yes, that Sylvia who is known for audio experiments, such as amplifying through a potato filter or hanging  her singers head down from the ceiling.

 

Sylvia and I want to make an album together. Sylvia wants it so much that she is willing to come to Prague to do it. I want to do it so much that I am willing to sell my kidney for it. 

Or perhaps raise money for the production which is never found in abundance with artists. My kind benefactor donated half of the money needed for the production. 

But I need to find the rest 

The pŕoduction budget includes mixing and mastering and taking part in Sylvia's adventure recording. We will be recording here in Prague from the 15th to the 30th of March Then Sylvia will be mixing the album in April /May in Oregon.  The album launch is planned for September.
